SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston, Sen Malcolm

TALK.START.PARA: —In my speech in the second reading debate on the Telstra bill, I indicated that negotiations and discussions between the government and me had not been concluded. I also indicated that, in the weeks prior to the vote for the second reading of this bill, I sought concessions for Queensland because I considered the partial sale of Telstra to be eventually inevitable. Those negotiations and discussions I referred to in my speech have now been concluded.

SPEECH.PARA: If the bill had been defeated on this occasion, and again after it had been reintroduced following a three‐month delay, it would have been odds on that the government would take the opportunity to dissolve both houses. The likelihood of the government being returned with a majority in the Senate would be remote. It would have been unlikely, on the other hand, that the government would not have a majority at any subsequent joint sitting.

The partial sale of Telstra would then become a reality. But would there be any opportunity to seek special concessions if the government had the numbers to force its proposal through, however tortuous that path may have been? The opportunities would not exist, as they similarly would not have existed if the government had decided to sell part of Telstra by non‐legislative means.

As I have outlined before, my principal concern with a part‐privatised Telstra is the continued employment of Telstra employees in rural and regional Queensland. I accepted the fact that technological advances would lead to staff reductions, but I was not prepared to accept that centres where telephone operators were located would close.

There had been suggestions that they could close, and there was even a suggestion that 013 operators' jobs could be outsourced to the Philippines. While that would be most unlikely, the closure of operators centres in rural areas was openly canvassed. I was able to achieve the aim of operators continuing to be located in the following Queensland centres outside the Brisbane metropolitan area: Ipswich, Gold Coast, Toowoomba, Nambour, Mackay, Maryborough, Rockhampton, Roma and Cairns.

My second aim was to keep any reduction of operator numbers in those centres to a minimum. In accepting the number of operators who will be employed in those areas, I had to take into account that the number of operators would be reduced in other areas of Australia. To this end, the number of operators in rural Queensland will reduce by 3.4 per cent between 30 September this year and the end of June 1999, compared with a Queensland‐wide reduction of 11.5 per cent and a nationwide reduction of 13.5 per cent.

In addition to the agreement on the O13 operators, Telstra has agreed to locate a national directory assistance call connect customer service centre in Toowoomba. It is a new service which allows a customer to ring Telstra, ask for a person's number and be automatically connected to that person. The service will be offered from a separate access code and will attract a fee.

Beginning in Queensland in 1998, this service will require the employment of 45 full-time staff by June 2000. These full-time operators are included in the percentage calculation of 3.4 per cent, which I have just mentioned. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table outlining the projected levels of staff through to June 1999 in the non‐Brisbane metropolitan operator centres in Queensland
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I accept the figures in this table, following assurances from the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) and Mr Blount, the Chief Executive Officer of Telstra. I realise that some honourable senators would not accept such assurances. But I do, because if assurances following negotiations are not kept, future negotiations would be of no avail.

BREAK.PARA: Nevertheless, I attach two caveats to that acceptance. First, I regard the staff figures in the table to be a minimum. Second, I believe that every senator for Queensland, and those members of the House of Representatives whose electorates include an operator assisted service centre, should make regular checks to ensure that the undertakings are fulfilled. I am sure that the unions representing the operators will be vigilant on the numbers employed in each centre.

It is my expectation that Telstra, as it develops its plans for the years beyond 1999, will see the benefit of employing operators in those regional centres of Queensland and will retain not only the centres in which the operators work but also the number of staff, at least at the 1999 levels.

A further aim during my discussions on this bill was to ensure that telecommunications services in rural Queensland are, as far as is practically possible, equal to those available in metropolitan areas. The $250 million which the government agreed to commit from the partial sale of Telstra over a five-year period will help this to occur. Queensland's share of $53.1 million will be invaluable for its rural telecommunications customers.

As the Minister for Communications and the Arts, Senator Alston, has said, the funds will focus on providing regional communities with additional opportunities through improved access to telecommunications infrastructure and services, increasing the amount and quality of training and educational opportunities and by providing better quality communications and information centres for regional businesses, public institutions and residents.

I expect the funds from the regional telecommunications infrastructure fund will be distributed by an independent board created to assess applications for funding under the program. I further expect that such a board would be supported by a secretariat within the Department of Communications and the Arts.

It should not be thought that all of the $53.1 million allocated to Queensland will be spent on capital items. It could be expected that a significant proportion will be used to provide wages, thus providing even more jobs in the rural areas of Queensland. I should imagine that similar effects will occur in other states.

I do not resile from having undertaken discussions with the government to benefit those whom I represent in this chamber. It was inevitable that Telstra would be sold, whether by legislative means or otherwise, and I would have been derelict in my duty if I were willing to forego an opportunity to achieve concessions for Queensland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —I wanted to get clarification of two things from the minister. One concerns the provisions aimed at consumer protection. What I was trying to ask previously was: why has a division 6 been put in there separately when there are already provisions in the existing act to look after consumer interests? This is indicated in schedule 1, item 5 which talks about timeliness and comprehensibility of the bills. That is to be put in at the end of section 38 and if you take section 38 with sections 347 to 349, that provides a code.

SPEECH.PARA: I was wondering why there is a separate division 6 for customer service guarantee and whether there is a lack of faith in the consumer provisions that are already there. If that is so, why has the government not changed them in respect of all matters, not only as to the periods of time that suppliers might take to connect, but also the quality of the service? Why are they separate issues? The other question was one which I think Senator Harradine may have the answer to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you asking him?
—No, I am not asking him. I would not.
—Why not?

—Because I want to ask the minister and Senator Harradine might want to think about this. In my previous speech I raised the problem of keeping the sale of Telstra to a third. The minister said that of course that would be so and it would be a little unusual that people would want to trade off more than a third. I would agree with those sentiments, but there are specific provisions in the proposed amendments which seem to contemplate that that might happen. I refer to proposed item 8AC which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Telstra must take all reasonable steps to ensure that a situation described in paragraph 8AB(2)(a) . . . does not exist.
In fact, if that does arise, Telstra will be guilty of an offence and will be convicted and fined not more than 500 penalty units.

I agree with the proposition put by the minister yesterday that it does seem strange that Telstra would get into a position where more than a third was sold. The minister assured me that that would be a ridiculous position to be in. If that is ridiculous, why is that provision in the proposed amendments? If the government wants to keep the sale to a third and no more than a third, why does it have provision 8BX which says:
An act is not invalidated by the fact that it constitutes an offence against this Part.
It is an offence to sell more than a third of Telstra and for that Telstra can be fined if it sells recklessly or otherwise. If the sale goes beyond a third, it does not make that sale invalid.

One way of keeping the sale of Telstra to a third and no more than that—in other words, one way of keeping the third from going beyond a third—would be to sell it by redeemable preference shares. Then if you do go beyond a third, you can redeem them back. It seems that a suggestion has been made that a great amount of capital can be raised by selling redeemable preference shares and that would ensure that no more than a third was sold. It would save the government having to put in a section which enables a court to fine Telstra and the government would not need to go to provision 8BX.

It has been said that the government might not get as much as otherwise, but that is a matter for the markets. We do not know what we will get until we see the prospectus in any case. It seems to me that the suggestion that has been made that the government has another look at this before it goes on would make the drafting of the legislation much more comfortable.

There are those two issues. Why do you have a separate provision, division 6, for the customer service guarantee when you already have one? You have left the one that is there without changing it in any substance, yet you are bringing in another regime. It seems fairly contradictory. I would like you to answer the consumer protection issue, if you could, and the issue of the creep in the size of the share of Telstra that is sold.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cooney does address a very important issue when he asks me about the customer service guarantee. That is not in current legislation, unlike a number of other consumer safeguard arrangements such as the right to untimed local calls, price caps and the universal service obligation. The customer guarantee is something that we developed specifically in the lead-up to the last election in recognition of the fact that quite frequently the carriers, particularly Telstra, do not honour their arrangements to keep appointments let alone maintain and service telephones within a reasonable period of time.

SPEECH.PARA: This provision is designed to ensure that they do and punish them if they do not by way of pecuniary entitlement which can, as you pointed out yesterday, be offset against your phone bill if necessary or if it is your choice. It is an entirely new provision. It is a world first for Australia. It does have regard to practices that I have observed elsewhere, particularly in the US and the UK, but to my knowledge no-one has taken precisely this approach. I think that is one of the reasons why the Australian Democrats finally came to the conclusion that the customer protection arrangements were so good that they wanted to get those pushed through the parliament as quickly as possible. It is over and above what is there already.

As far as the general notion that you should not be able to sell more than one-third is concerned, the starting point is political reality. No-one in this parliament would contemplate for a moment standing idly by and allowing Telstra, or indeed anyone else associated with the partial sale, to blithely contravene the act. If it were necessary I would not have thought there would be any shortage of volunteers to come into the parliament and do something about it, but that will not be a problem.

As you point out, there is already a provision that would punish Telstra to the tune of some $250,000 and would make it an illegal act if they were to consciously go beyond the one-third. A lot of consequences flow from illegal actions, as I pointed out yesterday. For example, any potential investor who entered into a contractual arrangement would be at risk of not getting their money back if they were a party to something they were aware was against the law. Senator Cooney referred me to 8BX, which reads:
An act is not invalidated by the fact that it constitutes an offence against this Part.

This part is actually part 2A, which commences on page 29 of the bill. That essentially relates to restrictions on foreign ownership and the limit we are putting in place, and some of the other provisions as well including that Telstra's head office, base of operations and place of incorporation are to remain in Australia, and that Telstra's chairman and a majority of Telstra's directors must be Australian citizens, et cetera.

I think it is fair to say that in that area you can have accidental overlaps which would need to be corrected. The Qantas float was a recent classic example of that. Therefore, that provision is designed to ensure that some accidental temporary overlap does not result in an invalidation of the whole sale exercise in relation to foreign ownership. But it does not in any way refer to the overall concept of the sale. Therefore, any breach would remain a breach and would not be overlooked by reference to that provision.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —Section 38 of the existing act does relate to the quality of performance by the carrier. Therefore, there is an obligation on the carrier to provide certain information under pain of financial penalty but also to provide a deal of information which then finds its way into Austel quarterly and annual performance reports.

PARA.BREAK: That is one of the bases upon which we have come to the view that Telstra's perform ance has been inadequate. In other words, particularly outside the metropolitan areas, we consistently find that the quality of service is declining—the length of time it takes to answer a phone call, the length of time it takes to get through to operator assisted services, the length of time it takes to get through to service difficulties and faults, for example.

SPEECH.PARA: All of those at the moment are simply dealt with by putting them on the public record. Section 38 simply enables or requires Austel to make public those deficiencies in Telstra's performance of customer satisfaction but does not take it any further. That is why the customer service satisfaction guarantee for the first time puts a legal obligation on Telstra to provide services within a fixed period, to install and maintain and keep appointments within a certain period, and if they do not you can get your money back.

TALK.START.PARA: —Your new provision doesn't say anything about quality.

—As I have said, you will continue to have quality of service reports provided by Austel, and that can form the basis for any future view on the part of the parliament that there should be an increased obligation imposed on carriers. As an outcome of the standard telephone service review report, which is due on 20 December, it is quite open to that group to recommend to the minister that we upgrade the minimum standards of quality of service. SPEECH.PARA: However, the customer service guarantee is over and above that. It deals specifically with defaults in terms of installation, maintenance and appointment keeping. So the combination of all these things is that you will get much more focus on Telstra's performance. We will have the ability to upgrade the minimum standard under the standard telephone service definition, and we will have the customer guarantee overriding all of the other general entitlements.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
REGIONAL TELECOMMUNICATIONS INFRASTRUCTURE FUND

The Regional Telecommunications Infrastructure Fund (RTIF) will seek to improve the quality of telecommunications infrastructure in rural and regional areas. The RTIF will be established to overcome some of the disadvantages that rural and regional telecommunications users face in terms of access and cost of advanced communications services that are currently available in metropolitan areas.

2. The broader objective of the program is to provide rural and regional communities with additional employment opportunities, increase the amount and quality of training services, increase access for schools to advanced communications services and electronic information sources, and provide better quality communications and information services for regional businesses.

3. The RTIF will be established as a Trust Fund under s62A of the Audit Act and funded at $50 million pa over a five year period commencing in 1997-98. The money will be paid as a one line Budget appropriation into the RTIF with annual appropriations coming out of the RTIF to meet estimated expenditure. Money will only be able to be expended in accordance with the purposes of an instrument establishing the RTIF.

4. The moneys will be allocated so that the share each State receives from the RTIF is in direct relationship to the share of that State's population which is found outside that State's capital city. A separate $20m component of the RTIF has been reserved for the two Territories. Allocations by State will be: NSW $37.4m; Vic $28.5m; Qld $53.1m; WA $26.5m; SA $26.5m; Tas $58m; NT $16m; and ACT $4m.

5. A Board of 3-5 people (including people with relevant expertise and knowledge of regional needs outside the Commonwealth Government) will be established to oversee the operations of the RTIF and to determine the allocation of funds to individual projects. The Minister for Communications and the Arts will not be involved in approving individual projects or payments out of the Fund.

6. The Department of Communications and the Arts will provide a secretariat to the Board. The Board will be responsible for the development of detailed eligibility criteria and processes, for promotion of the programs, for the processing and administration of applications and grant funds and the administration of evaluation processes.

7. Selection criteria for projects will be established by the Board following consultation with appropriate community groups, State and Local Government, industry organisations, the Chief Government Information Officer and other relevant Commonwealth agencies. Criteria would include (but not necessarily be limited to): demonstration of community demand and support; increased access and/or lower costs for users; and a viable business plan (taking into account assistance initially provided by the Fund). A detailed statement of selection criteria will be issued prior to calling of applications for funding of projects.

9. All projects funded under the program will be committed to a contractual agreement (based on the standard approach recommended by the Attorney-General's Department), giving full undertakings regarding detailed budgeting, business plan, audit arrangements and acceptance of program guidelines.

10. Administration of the Fund will be subject to the normal processes of review of Departmental Estimates by the Senate Legislation Committee. The Fund will be audited by the Auditor-General. For each year of the Fund's five-year life the Board will prepare and the Minister will arrange for tabling in Parliament of an annual report on the operations of the Fund. The report will include financial statements prepared in accordance with guidelines issued by the Minister for Finance and audit reports by the Auditor-General.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have provided in this document considerable detail about the way in which the fund is intended to operate. It is designed to be at arms-length. It is designed to allow decisions to be made on their merits. It does retain considerable capacity for the parliament to review any decisions and allocation of funds either through the esti mates process by the Auditor-General being involved, or through a range of other ways.

SPEECH.PARA: In case it is suggested by Senator Schacht or anyone else that somehow this does not go far enough, let me remind him of a couple of examples in my own portfolio area of which he ought to be very much aware. The Creative Nation policy document was released in October 1994. It simply contained an announcement in respect of the Australian multi‐media enterprise—$45 million. All that you got was the announcement. Ministers were still corresponding on which portfolio would take responsibility for the initiative several months later.

Industry consultation was required and continued into January 1995, and the commercial structure was not complete until December—well after the announcement. The executive administration and board structures were eventually decided upon in April 1995, some six months after the announcement. The DIST concessional loans program of $48.2 million over four years was announced in the 1994-95 budget as part of the Working Nation package. At the time of the announcement, the government had not developed policies for assessing applications, nor had it developed an administrative framework or delivery mechanism. The scheme was not operational until the end of 1994‐95.

Distinctly Australian was a $300 million package for arts and culture announced in the 1993-94 budget. At the time of the announcement, the government had not developed its cultural policy statement but stated that it would be developed within six months. The package also included tax incentives for encouraging owners of heritage listed properties to carry out approved conservation work. However, the administration process and competitive selection process remain to be developed. It was said at the time of the announcement that the strategies would be developed following a consultation process that had not at that time been established.

The TV production fund provided $20 million per annum for a period of three years commencing in 1995-96. At the time of the announcement it was stated that the detail of the fund and its administration would be finalised through extensive consultation involving all relevant groups. The government asked the ABA to conduct these consultations and report back to the minister by February 1995—in other words, an October 1994 decision.
I make this point not by way of criticism but simply to demonstrate that it is not at all unusual for governments to make announcements very much in the broad and then to flesh out the details later.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a deal, though. This is the sale of Telstra. It will never be repeated.

—What we are talking about here is the administration of a fund and the purposes of a fund. What I am saying to you is that in the document I have just incorporated in Hansard you will get much more detail than you ever got from any of those other announcements. Therefore, we are in a position to assure the Senate well ahead of these moneys becoming available in the next budget that the processes will be completely at arms length. They will be subject to very proper scrutiny on the part of the parliament, and the fund will be administered in the way that it ought to be in accordance with normal practice.

—I have to say that it is more than a little late but what we have is better than what we were getting last night from the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston). For an hour and a half last night, the minister ducked, weaved and swerved all over the place trying to answer very simple questions about the operation of this infrastructure trust fund. It is clear that overnight in desperation his advisers said, `Let's put together the paragraphs and table it as though this is some well thought out approach to government administration.'
—I had it last week. He should have put it in last night.
—You had it last week, did you? Well you are privileged, Senator Harradine. You are the most privileged senator in Australia. You are the most privileged politician in Australia.
—I don't know why he did not put it in last night. That is not my problem.

We are left with a board of three to five people. Can you imagine who they are rounding up for that? Some of the good old boys from out in the bush—all part of the old National Party rural network—to make sure the money is spent in the politically best way possible.

Minister, we know as well as you do that you do not have to be actually sitting at the table signing the cheques or allocating the money to get the desired political result. Amendments 1 to 3 seek to modify clauses 8AA and 8AB of the bill. I have moved them because I want to give some strength to Senator Harradine's proposal for a Senate inquiry. These amendments will ensure that the only shares that can be sold in Telstra will be redeemable preference shares. I am not sure at this stage about the redeemable preference shares proposal. I do not have a closed mind on it. I do at this stage think that it makes more sense to Telstra and to the government to raise finance by way of a bond issue than a float of redeemable preference shares. But, as I say, my mind is not closed.

One thing I do agree with Senator Harradine on, though, is that a float of redeemable preference shares is infinitely preferable to a float of ordinary shares. It is preferable for two reasons. First, it ensures that the control of the underlying assets of Telstra stay with the Commonwealth, stay in public hands. As Senator Harradine has repeatedly pointed out, a float of redeemable preference shares allows the government to raise $8 billion worth of revenue without surrendering control of the underlying assets of Telstra. I think that is really important. It is vitally important—this has been Senator Harradine's argument in relation to a whole lot of other entities—that, wherever there is basically a natural monopoly, it should remain in public hands.

The second reason that redeemable preference shares are preferable to the issue of ordinary shares is that the entire financing proposal is reversible. The preference shares would be redeemable at some later stage by a future government. When the budget deficit is properly repaired in years to come, and if the Telstra sale does not proceed, such repair will proceed far more quickly and a future government with a bit more foresight than both the former Keating government and the current Howard government about the value of assets could start redeeming the shares. I know that that is a big political ask, but we are not talking about the best option here.

It is not unusual for us to look at the reversibility of this situation. Each year billions of dollars worth of government bonds fall due and they are redeemed, usually by the issuing of new government bonds. A future government may decide—at least this gives them the option—to move the debt from Telstra redeemable preference shares to government bonds. I think the reversibility aspect of this is important because a lot of us here and a lot of Australians have not been convinced about this huge economic and social experiment of privatisation—in this case, a privatised Telstra.

We are not convinced privatisation of Telstra will be in the public interest. Who is to say whether in a couple of years time consumers will be happy with the outcomes, despite the minister's assertions? Who is to say what business will be thinking in a couple of years time? Who is to say how regional Australia will view what they see they have been given and how it actually works out in practice? Maybe a political party may be able to make promising to redeem the shares a very attractive proposition to Australian voters. So that is the attraction of Senator Harradine's proposal vis‐a‐vis ordinary shares.

I reiterate, though, for us it is very much a second best solution. We should not be issuing any shares of any type at all. Telstra should remain in total ownership by the Australian people. I believe the public sector would be much better off if the float of Telstra did not proceed. I want to raise the economic argument here that the public sector will be better off to the tune of $1 billion over four years, with that amount increasing. That increases to $2½ billion when retained profits are added to the equation.

This is what we are giving up. This is what we are losing. We might have some little deal for regional Australia. Nobody wants to disparage the opportunity for employment for any Australian, but let us not overlook what has been forgone in this arrangement. Not proceeding with the float means $2½ billion of taxes that will not have to be increased. This government has not said yet how it will make up the income stream forgone. It means $2½ billion worth of services that will not have to be cut if we do not sell off the profit stream.

I think it is a strong argument. I want to put it before a Senate inquiry with teeth—not a pathetic Senate inquiry whose report is preordained to go nowhere but a Senate inquiry where its final report will influence what is happening with the Telstra financing option. If my amendments are accepted, then Senator Harradine's inquiry will suddenly become very important. It will be looking at two issues: whether there are benefits for the public sector in moving down the redeemable preference share float option or whether the public sector would be better off not proceeding with the float but rather financing $8 billion worth of public debt through normal government Treasury bonds.

That would be a very interesting inquiry. I do not see any point in participating in an inquiry that is reduced to an academic exercise in proving Treasury wrong on its arguments even though you know full well it does not make one iota of difference at the end because this government will still proceed to an ordinary shares float. We know what Treasury think about this proposal. I think these amendments will keep Treasury honest. It will force them to seriously consider, just for once, whether they are better off with redeemable preference shares or Treasury bonds. That is why I am asking senators Harradine and Colston in particular to support these amendments.

The fourth amendment seeks to enhance the reporting arrangements of Telstra Corporation to the parliament by seeking to ensure that, where Telstra makes major changes to its staffing levels, they are reported to the minister as the investment manager for the majority Commonwealth shares, who must then seek the option of his or her principals, the Commonwealth parliament. If the principals, that is both houses of parliament, by resolution approve the plan, it proceeds.

This will give the parliament some control over Telstra's staffing levels. Obviously, in making an assessment, the parliament will balance the impact on staffing issues vis‐a‐vis dividends and profitability—not a radical proposal at all. Senator Colston in his remarks said that the guarantee or the safeguard for all of us over employment was for each senator for Queensland and each member of the House of Representatives for Queensland to monitor the implementation of the government's proposal. So what! We look at it; we monitor it. What can we do about it? We cannot do anything about it under the existing proposals.

Under this proposal, we are saying that the parliament, as the elected representatives of the majority shareholders, the two‐thirds, should have the right to decide whether it wants to trade off some aspect of dividends against maintaining employment.

There are a lot of other privatisation decisions which have been brokered through watchful upper houses and which have included guarantees about staffing. For example, the State Bank privatisation in New South Wales, in which my colleague Liz Kirby was involved, required no reduction in staffing numbers or branches for three years after privatisation.

My amendment is drafted in a similar vein, recognising that workers should not be the victims of privatisation. It is bad enough when privatisation results in a massive transfer of windfall gain from public hands to private hands with the undervaluing of asset prices, but then there is almost always this massive transfer of value from labour to capital as labour is stripped to the bone for a temporary—and it is always temporary—rise in dividends.

This amendment will ensure some protection against excessive and ludicrous downsizing. There are too many corporate cowboys out there who test their corporate virility by how many body bags they can produce. I have heard them in planes talking about how many faceless people they managed to downsize this month. It makes me sick. It makes me sick that people in secure jobs can always talk so callously about the people for whom there will be no jobs. Haven't they been listening to Stephen Roach, the so‐called guru of downsizing? He is saying that downsizing is short‐sighted. I am reminded that when Kim Beazley was minister he forced Telstra to shed 15,000 jobs. Then it started to expand again and they had to put most of them back on. That was a monumental waste of money, just as Roach would have predicted.

BZW has forecast that Telstra will have a 27 per cent profit improvement over the next three years despite falling market share, and that is with staff reductions of just 6,000 to 8,000. But there has been all this predication that Telstra was not going to be worth selling in years to come; all this talking down for months and months. And now, suddenly, when you want to sell it, it is miraculously worth a whole lot more in your view. To me, 22,000 seems excessive. It is all about inflating the Telstra float sale price. It is the same innocent people. If this sale did not happen, 22,000 workers might not lose their jobs, 22,000 families might not face the prospect of serious financial upheaval and the communities within which those 22,000 workers live would not face flow‐on job losses. Preserving 35 jobs in Toowoomba and 175 in Tasmania has to be placed in the context of losing 22,000 jobs over the rest of Australia.

Please support my amendment. You say that majority ownership of Telstra means public control. Let us give the public a say through the parliament—a say on what happens with Telstra jobs. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Today is International Human Rights Day. The Liberal‐National Party governments in the past have had a proud tradition in promoting and defending human rights. Will the minister outline the government's approach to human rights and examples of recent actions it has taken in this vitally important area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity on International Human Rights Day to reiterate our commitment to basic human rights and freedoms.
—You closed up shop in Queensland.

—I hope, Senator Faulkner, that that includes all of us. It also gives us the opportunity to ensure that we practice what we preach both domestically and internationally. Sadly, for far too many in the world community the basic human rights and freedoms that we take for granted are simply not available.

ANSWER.PARA: This government, consistent with the record of coalition governments in the past, is strongly committed to basic human rights and freedoms. I remind you that, under the Fraser coalition government, that commitment was recognised by Australia's election to the UN Commission on Human Rights in 1978, with a re-election in 1980. We voted on the Security Council for economic sanctions against South Africa. We ratified the International Convention on Civil and Political Rights. We took part in actions which we vigorously contributed to with others within the world community—in campaigns against abuses in Africa, in Asia and elsewhere.

As I said, that commitment has carried over to the Howard coalition government, which is just as determined that we will not only meet the highest standards of basic human rights and freedoms domestically but also contribute in a positive way to a better international environment in that regard.

Our approach to human rights is based on, first, a realistic assessment of what can and cannot be achieved; secondly, a constructive dialogue with other governments, including both bilateral and multilateral approaches; and, thirdly, working to strengthen democratic and human rights institutions, particularly in our region. We are prepared to use development assistance as a goal in that regard. For example, we are prepared to use a development cooperation program through AusAID to continue to support democratic development in human rights institutions in developing countries.

For example, I remind you that in PNG we are broadening our assistance in the law and order and justice area—$120 million for current and planned assistance. Another example is our assistance to a research centre for human rights in the Ho Chi Minh Academy of Political Sciences in Vietnam. I could continue, particularly with our own region but also on much of the developing world where we are constructively contributing to a better international environment.

I particularly bring to your attention a number of new initiatives in this area. We are supporting the establishment of an informal Asia-Pacific forum of national human rights institutions. We will provide $250,000 over three years, through the Australian Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, for the establishment of a secretariat to the forum.

The government is supporting the development of the Asia‐Pacific human rights arrangements, which will bring our region into line with Africa, the Americas and Europe. The government is proposing to establish a new centre for democratic institutions which would promote democracy and democratic change, particularly in the Asia-Pacific region.

We are strongly supporting the establishment of an international criminal court. We welcome the opportunity on International Human Rights Day to reiterate our commitment, in which we trust we are joined by all honourable parliamentarians within this institution. (Time expired)

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I refer to the Nairn report released today. In his media release Minister Anderson said, `Quarantine is a shared responsibility.' Is this code for less government involvement in quarantine protection? In particular, is AQIS to abolish the requirement for technical qualifications and competence for imported food inspectors? What qualifications are replacement administrative officers required to have in order to certify that imported meat will not contain contaminants such as salmonella or E. Coli? Will they be required to possess a base level qualification? Will it be science based and will it be mandatory?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Woodley has asked that question for two reasons. One is to talk about the Nairn report and the other is to talk about the industrial action that is now being started by the CPSU.
—Maybe he wanted an answer.

—I am happy to give answers on both if time permits, Senator Cook. The report of the review of Australia's Quarantine and Inspection Service is not a review of individual applications. It has nothing to say about them. The key theme of the report is that quarantine is a shared responsibility, as you have said, Senator. It is necessary for all governments, industry and very much the general public to take ownership of quarantine in this country. The minister has pointed out that there is a need for quarantine to be viewed as a continuum which incorporates offshore, border and post‐border measures, with each of these elements supporting and reinforcing the other.

ANSWER.PARA: The report refutes the belief held by some that we can adopt a no risk quarantine policy, as it would be untenable and totally impracticable. Australia's quarantine policy is not and cannot be one of zero risk. Such an objective would require the end of all trade and international travel. The report recommends a continuation of the use and refinement of scientifically based risk analysis. It recommends further improving current processes in terms of timing and the amount of consultation and communication, and it has provision for an appeal mechanism on process.

The report says that Australia's quarantine systems were generally in good shape and notes that much of the criticism about the effectiveness of AQIS cannot be supported by facts. However, the Commonwealth remains committed to maintaining a conservative quarantine policy to safeguard human, animal and plant health in Australia. The report recommends the creation of a statutory authority called Quarantine Australia to ensure political independence. There is a diversity of views on this issue, such as the recent Senate report on cooked chicken meat and the report of the national task force on fish and fish products.

There is a need also to have discussions with state and territorial ministerial colleagues.

ANSWER.PARA: The minister has established a steering committee within his department under the chairmanship of the departmental secretary to oversight a Nairn implementation task force. I think everyone in the Senate should appreciate the fact that, from a primary industry point of view, we export five times as much as we domestically consume in this country. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some information on an expected question in this area. It does not go specifically to each of the points of your question. I will give you the information that I have got and, to the extent that it does not answer any specific questions that you have asked, I will take those back to the minister.

ANSWER.PARA: I understand that the minister's comments on this issue have been taken somewhat out of context. What the minister was addressing was the myth that exists amongst some sectors of the community that the overseas born in general are more likely to be involved in criminal activity than are the Australian born. Australian and overseas studies have consistently shown that the overseas born commit fewer crimes and are less likely to be in prison than the Australian born.

According to the 1993 national prison sentence data, the overseas born prison rate of 86.9 per 100,000 was significantly lower than the Australian born prison rate of 131.6 per 100,000. This compares with rates in 1985 of 76.5 for overseas born and 107.53 for Australian born people. I suppose that simply shows that we are putting more people per thousand in prison; whether we are catching them doing the same number of crimes or more than that is not commented on.

All applicants for entry to Australia must be of good character, and character requirements are designed to exclude any person whose presence in Australia would not be in the interests of the broader Australian community. Persons who may be excluded from entry on character grounds include criminals or associates of criminal organisations, war criminals and any persons likely to vilify a segment of the community.

There is no particular problem with New Zealanders. The minister used the example of New Zealand migrants, who have a higher prison rate than some other migrant groups do, and who are not subject to the same screening arrangements as other migrants are, to illustrate how effective Australia's migration screening procedures are. They are not subject to the same screening arrangements as other migrants, because of the special relationship between Australia and New Zealand. Under the trans‐Tasman travel arrangement, Australian and New Zealand citizens may enter each other's country to visit, live or work without normal screening requirements. This joint arrangement between the Australian and New Zealand governments recognises the common historical, cultural, political and institutional history of the two countries. Being from a particular national or ethnic group does not make an individual more or less disposed to crime. The important point to make is that socioeconomic circumstances of individuals, irrespective of birthplace, are key determinants of the incidence of crime.

The Institute of Criminology statistics indicate a positive correlation between unemployment and higher prison figures, and, therefore, specific overseas born groups who experience high unemployment may have higher prison rates—but for that reason, not by reason of their place of birth. A prevalence of higher crime rates among some migrant groups is not because they are predisposed to commit crime or because the immigration character checks are ineffective but because they experience higher unemployment and lower socioeconomic status.

To add one more point, the prevalence of high unemployment amongst some migrant groups can be best addressed by refocusing the immigration program onto skilled migration and thus restoring the balance in the program. That would be one step that we could take. That is exactly what this government intends to do with the 1996‐97 intake. Senator, I think that does answer most of your questions but, as I have said, I will give this answer and your questions to Mr Ruddock. You cannot come in here one day saying that we are doing too much for them and then the next day saying that we are not doing enough for them.
—Why not?

—Senator Murphy says, `Why not?' That is indicative of the Labor Party's policy paralysis and the dilemma that they have. They do not know which way to turn and, in their embarrassment, they make silly interjections, like Senator Murphy has just done and which has assisted me in this contribution.

PARA.BREAK: The big ticket issues for the mining industry are quite clear; for example, industrial rela tions reform. Where was the Labor Party on IR reform? Against it every single inch of the way. What is the next big ticket item? Lower interest rates. What do the opposition say about lower interest rates? They bemoan the fact that we have succeeded in producing an environment which is now producing lower interest rates. Indeed, we are now having economic growth at the rate of 3.8 per cent. What does the shadow Treasurer say? The economy is as flat as the Nullarbor Plain. What a great economist Mr Gareth Evans, former Senator Evans, is when he makes statements like that in the context of 3.8 per cent growth.

SPEECH.PARA: What is another big ticket item for the mining industry? Waterfront reform. I think it was Senator Bob Collins who said, `If I don't reform the waterfront within a certain time, I will resign.' We have been waiting for his resignation ever since, because nothing has happened. Nothing happened in relation to the waterfront during the Labor Party reign. They knew something had to be done about it, but they did not have the political will to do something about it. We have and we will deal with it. The mining industry and the workers within the industry will benefit as a result.

What is another big ticket item issue for the mining industry? Rail reform. Over 13 years of Labor government, the rail system in this country went in a downward spiral. We have arrested that downward spiral and we have now committed ourselves to a fundamental reform of the rail industry and the rail infrastructure within this country—another big ticket item on which we are delivering for the benefit of the mining industry and those regional communities in Australia that rely on the mining industry, which is really the bread and butter for the outlying regions of Australia.

PARA.BREAK: We have also committed ourselves to cutting red tape for a lot of the small businesses that in fact get their livelihood from the mining industry. So the small businesses will benefit and be able to provide their services to the mining industry at a cheaper rate; therefore make it more profitable and allow for greater productivity and greater employ ment opportunities. But, once again, Labor during 13 years refused to deal with the red tape problem for small business.

SPEECH.PARA: What is another big ticket item for the mining industry? The Native Title Act. We all know about the problems that have been occasioned by the Native Title Act not only for the mining industry but also for the indigenous communities of this country who have been denied the possibility of latching onto the profitability of the mining industry and thus providing some economic support and economic independence for those communities. We have committed ourselves to making amendments to the Native Title Act to make it more workable for the mutual benefit of our indigenous communities, the mining industry and the wellbeing of all of Australia. Where is the Labor Party on that? Once again, they stand in opposition.

I have been able to detail half a dozen areas where we have been of real benefit to those people within the mining industry who derive their employment and their livelihood from it. apply conditions retrospectively to woodchip licences in order to meet Commonwealth obligations, and

PETITION.TITLE: Port Hinchinbrook Development Project
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PETITION.TITLE: Legislative Program

PETITION.TITLE: Threatened Species Legislation

The Commonwealth Threatened Species Bill recognises that Australia has the worse extinction record of native mammals of any country on Earth in recent history and that species extinctions are still occurring at an alarming rate.

Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should support Commonwealth Threatened Species legislation which uses the full powers given to it by the Australian Constitution and which provides the necessary financial resources to halt the loss of species on this, the oldest continent on earth.

PETITION.TITLE: Housing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned respectfully submit that Social Housing is a major social safety net, crucial for all Australians.

Your petitioners therefore call upon the Senate to maintain a commitment to the buying and building of new housing properties. Dismantling the safety net of Social Housing will mean homelessness, overcrowding and the scrapping of public housing redevelopment plans, all of which will impact on the most disadvantaged groups in the Australian society.
Your petitioners support an increase in assistance to low income earners in the private rental market, but not at the expense of Public and Community Housing.
Your petitioners thus urge the Senate to reject current plans in the area of public and community housing.
