TALK.START.PARA: —The President has received a letter from Senator Bolkus proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The deleterious effect of the Government's cuts and higher fees on access to the Family Court and related services.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to this matter of public importance on the deleterious effect of the government's cuts and higher fees on access to the Family Court and related services. The Family Court is a much maligned but nonetheless essential service in our community. It is a body that is there to resolve the most personal and most important of disputes. It is not surprising that many Family Court cases excite intense emotions and anxiety amongst the participants and the community.

SPEECH.PARA: All the major parties as well as the minor parties in this place support the ongoing role of the Family Court. Whilst many of us from time to time have been critical of aspects of its administration, we all overwhelmingly value the service it provides. The Family Court is surrounded by a series of support services. Some are provided within the courts, such as the court's own counselling and mediation service. Others are provided in the community. These include marriage and relationship education, adolescent and family mediation, family skills training and family mediation services.

The totality of these services is aimed at providing as flexible and as helpful response as possible to firstly prevent families entering into crisis and also supporting them in the event that they do. The objective of the parliament is that at the end of the day we want to see fewer divorces. We want to see more families stay together and we want to see those families that do separate do so amicably. We want to see more children have access to both their parents, their grandparents and their extended families. This is why the government cuts in this area are so mean spirited.

BREAK.PARA: In short, the cuts imposed by this government, this Howard government, will make it harder for ordinary Australians to access these essential services. An inability to access justice meted out by the Family Court or the assistance provided by the related services means more family turmoil, more heartache, more despair. It is damage flowing from these cuts that simply cannot be measured by economists. It is damage to the very fabric of our society and something that we should not tolerate.

So let us look at these cuts. Firstly, in terms of the Family Court itself, the government promised in the election campaign to cut $2 million a year from the court's budget. They claimed this would be merely efficiency gains by the court. But it did not take long for this promise to be proven false. The court's budget has been cut by $3½ million in 1996-97 after the so-called public sector wide efficiency cuts, the Attorney‐General's Department efficiency cuts and the loss of Justice Statement funding are all taken into account.

The cuts do not end there, for the forward estimates show that the court will face a further cut of $10 million in real terms in 1997-98—big cuts and the impacts are deep. For instance, in terms of the consequence of these cuts, registries at Mackay and Bendigo have already been closed. Another at Launceston has been reduced to a counselling registry and even that is under threat. The registries at Geelong, Rockhampton and Wollongong are at risk.

The daily reduction programs in Melbourne and Parramatta were suspended, although high demand has forced the reinstatement of the Parramatta program on a more limited basis. The delays in the Melbourne registry have become so bad that practitioners there openly talk about over 1,000 cases that have disappeared into the waiting list black hole at that registry alone.

Circuits to regional areas have also been severely reduced. Circuits have been reduced to Albury, Ballarat, Bendigo, Geelong, Launceston, Mount Gambier, Traralgon, Warrnambool and Whyalla. But they are the lucky ones. Burnie, Griffith and Wagga Wagga will not be visited at all.

The loss of Justice Statement funds will mean that the provision of two family consultants to service remote and regional centres will not go ahead. The Cairns registry will not be upgraded to a filing registry as promised and outreach programs to Campbelltown in New South Wales and Logan and Ipswich in Queensland will not proceed. Only 19 of the 39 new Family Court counsellors promised in that Justice Statement Australia wide will now be employed—less than 50 per cent.

As I previously implied, related services will also be deeply affected. First, there is the Family Court mediation and counselling service. The Family Court Amendment Bill 1996, which is currently before us, seeks to allow the court to charge a $40 per hour fee for this service.

The concern of the opposition in this place in respect of the introduction of these fees is twofold. Firstly, there are deep access to justice implications in slugging families in crisis with a $40 fee for the provision of the service. Ultimately, this service does save the government money because it helps reduce the rate of divorce. Secondly, we are concerned about the longer term objectives underlying the bill.

In respect of this bill and the charges being implemented by the government, this is yet another breach of this government's election commitment to the Australian people. In its law and justice policy, the coalition promised to:
. . . support and implement moves to increase counselling, conciliation and mediation options for resolutions of disputes.

A measure such as this one, which makes it harder for people to access mediation and counselling services because of the imposed fees, hardly supports or increases the options that are available to Australian families in crisis.

PARA.BREAK: But the cuts do not end there. Government cuts mean that the family skills training services that were to be provided under Labor's Justice Statement this financial year in the Richmond-Tweed area, Central Mur rumbidgee, Shepparton‐Mooroopna, Bendigo, Ballarat, Gold Coast, Wide Bay‐Burnett or the Greenough River region will not proceed. We can also look at the adolescent and family mediation services which were to be provided this year and next in Newcastle, the Clarence, Geelong, Whyalla and Preston. They will also go.

BREAK.PARA: The range of programs that this government is prepared to cut is amazing. It does not stop there. Family mediation services which were to be opened in Gosford, Newcastle, Wollongong, the northern outer suburbs of Melbourne, Geelong, Bendigo, Ipswich, Wide Bay‐Burnett or Perth's south‐eastern metropolitan area simply will not be provided.

A whole range of services have been ditched—services that are critical to families in crisis and services that are critical to regional families in crisis. On top of those, we can look at the court fees. This government has made concessions to Senator Harradine, and I must say that we have not as yet seen the colour of those concessions or the regulations. It is getting very close to Christmas and the parliament will soon adjourn, and the Attorney-General is sitting on those regulations. They need to be brought forward immediately. Despite those concessions they will still garner a massive $90 million over the next four years out of the Family Court system.

Fees for a typical family law case will increase from some $368 to over $1,700. That is before anyone pays one cent to their lawyer. These fees are not user pays; they are basically a rough tough on families in crisis, a tax with devastating consequences on the families and on the fabric of our society. They are not going to deter the rich. The extremely poor will not be adversely affected because some of them will still be able to get legal assistance. The people who will suffer from these fees will be the new emerging group in our society, the group that is progressively being identified as Howard's losers.

I must say that this is not where it stops in terms of funding to legal aid. The ramifications of the cutbacks in legal aid on the family law system are also quite deep and pervasive. We had an assurance from the Attorney-General that cuts to legal aid funding would mean more money for family law cases, but despite this we are already seeing caps placed on the funding. For example, in Victoria there is a cap of $15,000 on existing cases, with a cap of $10,000 on new ones.

What is happening already is that we are finding the intellectually disabled having to represent themselves and fathers being forced to cross‐examine their own children when allegations of incest have been made. This is a government which does not care about access to justice and which does not care about families. It is depriving families and Australian citizens in general from access to the most basic services in our court system.

These cuts are wide, deep and all pervasive. In terms of their motivation, they are quite mean spirited. These sorts of cuts we are talking about are despicable. There is no over‐arching financial imperative, no matter how real or imagined, that can justify the sorts of ramifications we are talking about from the federal government's cuts in this area. They must be reversed and we should put pressure on the government to do so.
As Chief Justice Brennan said in what I think has been noted as an unprecedented statement in September this year:
It is not an overstatement to say that the system of administering justice is in crisis.

This government is responsible for that. This government is responsible for bringing this crisis around. Nowhere is this crisis more evident than in the case of our family law system. This government ought to be condemned for what it is doing to access to justice in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset let me say that, if the judicial system is in crisis, then the responsibility for that has to be borne by the former government. This certainly did not happen in the last eight months—that is, if it did happen. The truth is that the situation is nowhere near as serious as Senator Bolkus has portrayed.

SPEECH.PARA: The government came to power with an election commitment for a $2 million cut to costs and the Family Court and a further funding cut of $1.65 million to programs initiated under the previous government's Justice Statement. Also, there is a two per cent reduction which is demanded through the efficiency dividend. So there are no great surprises here in relation to these cuts. There is nothing that has been hidden from the Australian people. It was on this platform that the Australian people elected this government.

The other aspect that Senator Bolkus touches on is that of higher fees. In relation to the Family Court, the proposed fee for ancillary relief was proposed at $250. However, after negotiations and consultation, the government reduced this to $150. As well as this, the government reduced the proposed one‐off hearing fee from $400 to $300. To partially offset that, the government agreed to an increase in fee for divorce applications from $460 to $500.

The government announced all these proposed increases in the 1996-97 budget. It was as a result of finding the $8 billion black hole which the previous government hid from the people of Australia. It was in relation to that sad state of affairs of Australia's finances that this government had to take the course of action it took. It took it across the board—not just in relation to the judicial system, not just in relation to legal aid or the Family Court, but across the board.

In relation to the question of related services, Senator Bolkus has raised the question of a deterioration in counselling and mediation services. The first thing is that the $40 an hour fee is only in respect of voluntary counselling as opposed to counselling which is ordered by the courts. There will be exemptions for those who cannot afford it. So at the end of the day you will not have a counselling fee for that which is ordered by a court, and you will not have it applying to people who cannot afford it.

The Attorney‐General in the National Press Club on 15 October this year said he was keen to maximise access to primary forms of dispute resolution such as mediation and counselling and to ensure that those services are provided in the most efficient and effective way. He said such services were less expensive and traumatic ways of resolving family law disputes than litigation.

Senator Bolkus appears to be saying that capping legal aid at $15,000 is denying people access to the Family Court. The Attorney‐General has said it is better to try to resolve matters by mediation and counselling than to throw money at litigation and that if you must have litigation cap the fee so that it can be spread evenly across those who need it. The choice in legal aid is always whether to spend thousands of dollars on one case and so deny others a chance of representation. Capping provides more people with access to legal aid and representation.

Regarding counselling services, Senator Bolkus overlooks the fact that there are some 288 venues around the country where counselling services are funded by the Commonwealth. In regional areas, where there are Family Court closures, community‐based services may be required to pick up counselling work that would be otherwise done by the court. The government has not overlooked the ramifications of any closure. These changes will have an impact on community‐based services and the Attorney‐General's Department and peak bodies representing these agencies are working with the Family Court to develop protocols for sharing the responsibility for providing the range of counselling services needed to support all the requirements of the Family Law Act.

This government is aware of the problems that might arise from these necessary closures and is addressing them through consultation and mediation. It is easy for an opposition to criticise the government and say cuts in counselling and the fees are too high and people are denied access to the Family Court and that legal aid is being cut back. But the opposition is unable to show where people have been turned away from the Family Court because they could not afford to apply. The opposition has failed to say that 40 per cent of all fees are waived due to exemptions for people on social security, getting legal aid, or successfully showing the court they cannot meet the filing fees entailed.

It was not just a peremptory act by the Commonwealth to bring in these fees; it had been in the pipeline for some time. When the opposition was in government it was looking at exactly the same fee increase. It knew cost recovery in the Commonwealth jurisdiction was poor, to say the least. The increase in these fees will barely take the Commonwealth to the same levels of cost recovery as the states. It is irresponsible of us only to meet the needs of today without planning for the needs of tomorrow. We have to make sure our financial planning will allow for an increased legal aid system in the future, a more efficient Family Court system, and it may be tough decisions will have to be taken in the meantime and we will have to look at rationalising some of the registries we have.

One of the proposals mooted is the briefing out of counselling services. I can tell Senator Bolkus that the Family Court of Western Australia, which received much praise in the Joint Standing Committee on Family Law Matters for its efficiency, does not rely on court counsellors as such as other family courts in Australia do, but briefs work out to the family services to provide counsellors at the court. It operates in a most efficient manner. I hold up the practice of the Family Court of Western Australia as a good example. Use could be made of magistrates and country courts for Family Court access for those in regional areas. The joint standing committee mentioned that in its report last year.

The government has approached this in a thoroughly rational manner. It has to be dispassionate in looking at this problem. It has to look at the question of cuts on the one hand and balancing that with fees and cost recovery on the other and the question of access to justice. Involved in that question of access to justice is how high do you go with your fees and to what extent you make the legal aid dollar go further. The capping of fees is not a bad start in that regard. None of the cuts were a surprise; they were contained in the government's election commitments and I dispute the $10 million figure Senator Bolkus has raised regarding the year after this. The cuts we are dealing with are before the parliament and are ones mentioned by the government as I stated.

BREAK.PARA: There has been no evidence to date to show these higher fees have stopped anyone from using the Family Court. Senator Bolkus could not give us any evidence. He mentioned the scenario of a father cross‐examining his children in the Family Court. I find that hard to believe. In a Family Court there are discretionary powers about evidence from juveniles. That discretion is exercised most cautiously for obvious reasons. I dispute that example and refute it entirely as being the result of any cut or increased fee imposed by this government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne, Sen Vicki

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats are also extremely concerned with the impact higher court fees are already having on Family Court services, particularly on those users of the system who represent some of the most disadvantaged and disempowered citizens of this country—women. We heard a lot about family values during the election, but once a family starts breaking up those values seem to start breaking up too, especially with this government.

SPEECH.PARA: The rate of reported violence against women and children is also on the increase. As far back as 1992, Dr Hilary Astor, in her report Violence against women for the Office of the Status of Women, cited the time immediately after separation as the most physically dangerous time in a woman's life. In 1988, a survey by the Office of the Status of Women illustrated that nearly one-fifth of respondents—one person in five—believed that violence against a wife is sometimes justified. Violence against a wife is never justified. The respondents were both men and women. Lesser forms of ill‐treatment, such as denying money and yelling abuse, were even more widely accepted. This is a really shocking finding.

This is the environment that some of the most crucial services of the Family Court are frequently called upon to deal with. In 1992 the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act reported that following divorce living standards of non-custodial parents, generally males, increased markedly while living standards of custodial parents, usually the mother, and their children dropped.

BREAK.PARA: The Australian Institute of Family Studies undertook two studies on the aftermath of divorce. Settling up was published in 1986 and studied the economic consequences of divorce. In 1993 the Australian Institute of Family Studies published Settling down, in which the lives of divorced parents with dependent children are followed in the period five years to eight years following the breakdown of their marriage. In Settling down, they concluded:

The duration of dislocation and disadvantage was quite variable in this population of parents. Men usually recovered, and in many cases attained a higher standard of living within three years of separation; women suffered a severe drop in their standard of living which remained over the early years. Five to eight years after separation, the gap had lessened, an amelioration largely accounted for by the formation of new family units. The difference in magnitude and direction of the immediate effects of marriage breakdown on mothers with children and on fathers, and its long-term continuation unless the mother repartners, is one of the most confronting findings of this study.

So we find that the people who are most worried about higher fees are the people who have the least money, and that is generally the person who has the children in a relationship. They are the ones who are suffering most.

The Office of the Status of Women found in 1995 that 80 per cent of women and 73 per cent of men were worried about violence impacting on their lives. There is no mistake about this. When the primary care giver of children—and that is of course most often women in this country—is subject to emotional, physical, psychological or economic violence, and that happens very often after divorce and during divorce, then the children are also victims of that violence.

The coalition parties did make a pre-election promise to maintain funding to legal aid, and we have seen what has happened to that. It is doubtful that legal aid as we know it will now survive in this country. In the law and justice policy statement, the coalition parties stated, `All people should be equal before the law.' How true. They also said, `All people, regardless of status or financial means, should have the ability to access the law.' I would have to agree with that one, too.
The Access to justice report refers to not only the importance of legal aid for disadvantaged groups but also the level of fees in accessing the judicial system. It states:

The most obvious barrier to justice is the financial one. This, of course, affects many people in the community, especially in time of high unemployment. But as the Australian Law Reform Commission has pointed out insufficient money is a barrier which affects women to a greater extent than men because women generally have fewer financial resources than men. There are other barriers besides lack of financial resources. People who do not speak English face difficulties both in obtaining adequate information about the legal system and in communicating with many of the people and organisations that form part of it. Presenting even more difficulties are cultural barriers. For example, recently arrived immigrants may be reluctant to resort to the legal system when they come from countries where the legal system is a tool of oppression and judges, lawyers and police officers are among the oppressors. In less extreme cases, many people will face a barrier as the result of a fear of what they perceive to be (and not without reason) an intimidating, unpredictable and complex system. Less dramatic but equally important, difficulties arising from geographical location present considerable barriers for many Australians living outside population centres.
By way of illustration, we should look at the closure of the Launceston Family Court.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you know about that?
—The Launceston Family Court is closing; that is what we know about that, Senator Abetz. Let me give you a few more facts. In November, Senator Murray said:

BREAK.PARA: It has been estimated that 60,000 people will miss out on legal aid next year. Probably less than 15 per cent of Australians currently have access to legal aid. Last year in Western Australia, 70 per cent of the people who applied for legal aid were denied it, and that is under the old system. The section of the Attorney-General's Department that administers legal aid received a 6.6 per cent pay increase. There have been cases reported of adolescent children having to interpret for their mothers in protection applications where there has been domestic violence.

These are all demonstrations that what we need is more sensitivity. What we need is more money, obviously, into the Family Court system. We do not need cuts in funding to legal aid. The last thing we need is higher fees in access to the Family Court, and that is what we are getting under this government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a crisis in the legal system. That would be a matter of great regret to people who are in this chamber and people who are listening around Australia. Legal aid gives people proper representation before a particular court they may come to. It has to be remembered that lawyers are an essential part of the way this society runs and it is either a better society or a worse society, depending upon, firstly, whether or not there are lawyers to represent people and, secondly, the level of that representation.

SPEECH.PARA: A person accused before a criminal court should have somebody representing him or her. That is not my statement; that is a statement of the highest court in this land. What is happening now in the Family Court is that gross—and I use the word advisedly—injustice is being done. Some mention was made earlier about the position of children. What is happening now is that children who are involved in Family Court proceedings at times need their own representation.

The situation has developed to a point where a judge in the Family Court can request the legal aid commission in a particular state to provide support for representation for a child or children, and the legal aid commission—I know this has been the case in Victoria, for example—has, as it were, overruled what the judge has said, so legal aid has been refused. So a judge may request legal representation for a child, who may well be of tender years, who has absolutely no responsibility for the situation he or she is facing, who needs by the very judgment of the court that is hearing the case legal representation, but the legal aid commission concerned refuses that representation because it has insufficient funds.

PARA.BREAK: Judges in effect are being overruled not in a court of appeal but by a legal aid commission, because of lack of funds is a very bad situation to have. Something has to happen. Either funds have to be made available or our legal system has to change. We as a community, as a society, cannot allow the situa tion to continue where people cannot, because of a lack of funds, exercise the rights we as legislators give them. It is wrong to have one group of litigants who are well endowed with resources and the ability to put their case against people who are much more disadvantaged because they do not have the resources of, if you like, character, education and experience to face up to an opponent or the funds to engage a lawyer to present their case.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Ellison spoke earlier about a father cross‐examining a child. One would hope that would not happen, but we can well imagine what would happen if a wife wanted to cross-examine her husband or a husband wanted to cross-examine his wife in circumstances which are quite vicious if the opportunity were presented to one party to be vicious against another and a judge felt disinclined to intervene because, if he or she intervened, the impartiality expected of judges may well be compromised.

The issue of lack of funding cannot be put aside by simply saying it is a budget measure and every area of our society and our community must take cuts. It is true that the government has been elected and the government has said there will be cuts. That must be taken into account, but I think we are avoiding our obligation to society and to those who are brought before the courts, whether it be the Family Court, a criminal court or a civil court, if we simply say that, due to budget measures, unfortunately some people cannot have representation. If we are going to say people cannot have representation, then we have to do something about the legal system. We cannot have it both ways. We have to change the legal system—perhaps make it more of an inquisitorial system—change the function of judges or do something, but we cannot in all conscience continue in the direction we are headed.

I notice that sitting on the opposite side of the chamber are Senator Ellison, Senator Coonan and Senator Abetz, all eminent lawyers in their own right. They would understand what I am saying. They, together with everybody who is a lawyer in this chamber—indeed, everybody who is in this chamber—have to face up to this crisis that has developed. I use the word `crisis' advisedly. The private profession says that the system is not as it ought to be. Clients certainly say that the system is not as it ought to be. Judges and chief justices say it is not as it ought to be. We really do have to face up to what needs to be done.

This situation has gone beyond the party political stage. Certainly, in this chamber there are exchanges on a party political basis, and that should be kept going in this particular aspect, as with all aspects of society. But, above and beyond that, we have to solve this problem that we as a community are faced with and decide, as I have said a couple of times during this speech, whether or not we are going to change the system, increase the legal aid that is available or do a bit of both. We just simply cannot keep saying it is a budget problem and therefore do nothing. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coonan, Sen Helen

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose the matter of public importance, and I utterly reject the sentiments and assumptions implicit in the wording `the deleterious effect of the Government's cuts and higher fees'. The reason I oppose it is that, with the exception of Senator Cooney's contribution, what we have heard so far has been simplistic, piecemeal and even disingenuous in that those opposite have tried to explain the misery and failure of separation, divorce and domestic tension as being effected or contributed to by cuts and higher fees in the budget.

SPEECH.PARA: As with most areas of human behaviour, to begin to understand the complex processes of family law it is necessary to take a holistic approach not only to the families caught up in domestic conflict but also to the institutions that serve those families and provide the infrastructure to work through the problems.

I speak about this topic with some feeling because, in my early years as a legal practitioner, I did practise extensively in family law and I am currently a trained mediator, so I do have some considerable experience in this most difficult field.

Clearly, in such a complex area as the dynamics of family breakdown, there needs to be an ongoing evaluation of the Family Court and it needs to be charted as to how effectively it can deliver services and at what cost to both users and the community. Of course, the starting point is that the annual costs of running the Family Court now exceed $100 million. Added to that, just last year the report of the parliamentary Joint Select Committee into the Funding and Administration of the Family Court—headed, I might say, by South Australian Labor MP Martyn Evans—rejected calls for more Family Court funding. They said that throwing more money at this problem was not really what it required and they found that the court was living beyond its means like a person living on bankcard. There were some quite extraordinary examples of administrative costs. The chief executive was one example, having spent a little over $208,000 over four years commuting backwards and forwards between Sydney and Canberra. For the purposes of the Senate committee, the Family Court had some difficulty even articulating a comprehensive statement of what its core business really was.

Few would dispute the need for the Family Court to make efficiencies to better streamline its administration. Given, of course, the $8 billion budget deficit that the government inherited, it was only fair and reasonable that the Family Court, like all federal departments, should shoulder its share of the burden in reducing public sector outlays and meeting budget savings targets.

As Senator Ellison said, it was not as if the budget cuts and the fees were just imposed on the Family Court. In fact, the Family Court was asked to consider how it might make these savings. Most of the litany read out by Senator Bolkus were efficiencies which the Family Court has made of its own volition. What is particularly short‐sighted about motions such as the one being discussed today—at least at the level of the discussion—is that they zero in on costs and fees without even acknowledging the substantial reforms and shift in focus in service delivery that underpin increases in the Family Court fees.

The government recognises the value to families of access to primary forms of dispute resolution such as mediation and counselling, and the good sense of that is obvious. If you can actually assist people before their marriage or relationship completely breaks down, if you can work out what there is to salvage before they are embroiled in the adversarial system, it makes a great deal of sense to do so. In fact, it is perfectly obvious that it assists not only the individual partners but their children, their grandparents and, in fact, the community, if some way can be worked out without the cost, expense, delay and bitterness which inevitably follows an adversarial bout in the Family Court.

To that end, the government's thinking is that these services are best delivered by a mix of court and community sectors in appropriate geographic areas. Part of the structure of the new reforms and fees highlights the important role that private and community based mediation services can play as alternatives to the Family Court. I would have thought that those on the other side would have welcomed the fact that the government is thinking creatively, in an innovative way, about how to emphasise the value of mediation based services.

It is this belief that underlies the charging of a fee equivalent to that charged by community based counselling services for voluntary counselling access through the Family Court. The fee, of course, is $40 an hour, but only for voluntary counselling. So those poor unfortunate individuals, those poor unfortunate Australians, who end up in the Family Court as part of an adversarial contest will not be asked to pay for counselling or mediation. Of course, the thinking behind it was that it was inequitable, that some get the service free and others pay—it stands to reason.

I do agree with Senator Cooney that there is something to be said for looking at how the Family Court can structure greater efficiencies. The legal profession clearly has a role to play in this. In the past, the legal profession has, from time to time, risen valiantly to these sorts of challenges. A cap on fees is just one such challenge. Aspects of family law have been around since 1974 in their current form with a few amendments here and there. But basically, while there can be complex cases, and there always will be, not every case is so complex that it is going to be disadvantaged by the placement of a reasonable cap on a legal aid service.

Senator Bourne talked about the fact that a lot of people are denied legal aid. But, of course, the numbers reflect people who may not have been eligible in the first place. That figure bears no relation to those who have been refused legal aid, who otherwise might have been eligible and who were denied legal aid on the basis that funds were not available. The figure is just nonsense.

Senator Cooney also talked about separate representation, which is an issue of great concern. Unfortunately, time is going to beat me on this, but the shift in focus to mediation, the imposition of increased fees on those who can afford it, the waiver of fees for those who cannot and the better targeting of delivery of services will ensure that the family law system is one that responds to individual needs at a time of the very greatest vulnerability.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds, Sen Margaret

TALK.START.PARA: —Both Senator Ellison and Senator Coonan have made valiant efforts to justify cutbacks. However, I note that both of them looked extremely uncomfortable about their justification, because it is very hard to justify cutbacks in such a sensitive area of public policy. I accept some of the comments that have been made about wastage in administration. I accept that savings could have been made in that area. However, the majority of the cutbacks I am concerned about are impacting on ordinary families. This decision comes from a government that went into the last election saying how pro family they were. However, every decision relating to the family seems to me to be asking the family to pay and pay again.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Ellison said that none of these cuts would come as a surprise. I am sure that they will come as a surprise to families who will find out that the cost of a family law dispute will go from $368 to over $2,000. It may not come as a surprise to him, but it would certainly come as a surprise to those families. The user‐pays principle is a denial of justice. Senator Coonan obviously has experience and skills in mediation. I am sure she understands the hardship and emotional trauma that so many families go through. They do not need the additional burden of financial costs in relation to the provision of services.

I would like to put on the public record some of the problems that we are facing in Queensland. The proposed changes will mean the closure of the Mackay family registry. The Rockhampton registry is still at risk and its future has not been clarified. The Cairns registry will not be upgraded. Plans to establish a Gold Coast registry have been abandoned. Outreach programs in Logan and Ipswich will not proceed. Anyone who knows Logan and Ipswich as areas of extensive populations will know that it is just not good enough to tell families there that they will have to go into Brisbane. It is a very dense population region. Outreach programs in those two areas are most important.

The introduction of the user‐pays charges will mean $40 per hour for counselling services. Why would you go to counselling if you have a cost burden at that rate? Families are struggling as it is. They will not choose to use counselling, because it will be seen as too expensive. In those families where one or other partner, usually the male, is reluctant to go to counselling, that $40 per hour will act as a deterrent.

Cuts to visiting programs by judges, court staff and counsellors will result in a 50 per cent reduction in services to regional areas. I know that a number of people in Queensland are very concerned about the impact. I have a letter that I would like to read from the Family Law Reform and Assistance Association in Gladstone. I will summarise it, given the time. It states:
Our association protests in the strongest possible terms to the charges which will now be levied in Family Court matters contained in the coalition budget . . .
In case you are not aware it will now cost $460 to file for a divorce, $250.00 to file any application in the Family Court, $40.00 for a compulsory one half hour conciliation conference . . .
Organisations such as this one are very disturbed about the impact.

Earlier this year, the Queensland Law Society Family Law Committee Chairman Peter Sheeley said that the major concern was for country lawyers and their clients, who would have to travel to major regional centres to have cases attended to and heard. Mr Sheeley said that successful counselling in the early stages could contain the costs of divorce to under $1,000 compared with bills of many thousands of dollars for protracted cases. He predicted that these higher charges could be very detrimental to many families, particularly regional families.

I return to Senator Ellison's statement that these charges were not unexpected. I have a memo from the Family Court of Australia. That they were obviously surprised is evident from this five-page document that details just some of the cutbacks that will have to proceed and are now in the process of proceeding. There is the closure of the Bendigo subregistry. The delay reduction programs in Parramatta and Melbourne have been cancelled. Library subscriptions have been reduced by 50,000. When family law personnel cannot keep up with their reading, it is pretty petty of government.

Outreach activities will be eliminated other than minor expense travel. This is in a country like Australia, where one-third of the population lives outside capital cities. There will be the non-replacement of Justice Butler in Launceston when he retires later in the year. Clearly, Launceston will be badly affected. There will be the closure of the Rockhampton, Wollongong and Geelong registries. Pre‐filing counselling and mediation activities have been abandoned. Senators have commented positively about mediation, yet this memo indicates that pre‐filing counselling and mediation activities will be abandoned specifically because of budget cuts. These budget cuts in family law, of all areas, simply indicate that the coalition rhetoric is inappropriate. (Time expired)

—Let it go down on record that Senator Reynolds has, once again, committed the Labor Party to increase taxation or increase debt—take your pick. Where was there a substantial increase? It was in marriage and relationship education services. We committed an extra $6 million over three years. The Labor Party are the ones who would send the ambulance to the bottom of the cliff. —We believe that that is a lot better social and economic policy, but Senator Reynolds continues to interject. Let her go to the people of Australia at the next election and say, `We support the ambulance mentality, rather than the safety fence mentality.' We more than doubled our commitment in relation to marriage and relationship education services. TALK.START.PARA: —The time for consideration of the matter of public importance has concluded.
—In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor‐General:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Report No. 18 of 1996‐97—Performance Audit—Maralinga Rehabilitation Project—Tendering and Commercial Arrangements— Department of Primary Industries and Energy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

This report is quite important because the long‐term consequences of nuclear testing at Maralinga and also at Montebello are still with the Australian community, are still with many individuals who were affected by nuclear fallout and are still with the Australian landscape. The audit report basically goes into the project of rehabilitating the Maralinga site. Those who know anything about nuclear testing at Maralinga will know that it was a process that took place over a long period of time. There were a number of tests that occurred at Maralinga over a number of years which caused the nuclear fallout. They were above ground tests, airburst tests, and so on.

My concern is principally in relation to the people who were affected by nuclear testing. All of the work at Maralinga and also at Montebello is carried out by a unit in the Department of Primary Industries and Energy known as the test site management unit. My concern is the veracity and the accuracy of the records that are kept by the test site management unit. I will illustrate what I mean.

Recently, a friend's father died of cancer. He had been a national serviceman on board HMAS Culgoa. Whether or not his cancer was attributable to his presence at the Montebello tests is a matter for debate. But what is clearly not debatable is the lack of accuracy in the records that are kept by the test site management unit. The test site management unit maintains that at 8 a.m. on the day in question—that is, the time at which the first Montebello test occurred—the Culgoa was 1,000 nautical miles south-west of Montebello.

It is quite impossible for the Culgoa to have been there because, in fact, at midnight—just eight hours before the test—the Culgoa went over the bar at Carnarvon to discharge the ship's cook, who, I understand, had appendicitis. The Culgoa was only capable of a maximum speed of about 19½ knots and cruised at around 15½ knots. Therefore, it was not possible for the Culgoa to be at the site that the test site management unit claimed it was at.

That is a reason for some concern, because the test site management unit is responsible for maintaining the records on which the servicemen and civilians who are claiming to have received cancer caused by nuclear fallout are reliant. In other words, they have to go and prove their case using records maintained by the test site management unit. If the accuracy of those records is so poor, we need to do something to ensure that the situation is rectified. When you see records that are so inaccurate, it is clear that something needs to be done.

What honourable senators may not be aware of is that there was a special administrative arrangement to provide compensation for people who were affected by the nuclear fallout. That was put in place in 1989. But what occurred a couple of years ago was that the previous government substantially reduced the opportunity for people to claim. Now people only have a right to claim if the first signs of their cancer manifested themselves within 20 years of the test to which they were exposed.

Montebello occurred in 1956 and Maralinga occurred through the late 1950s and early 1960s. There are very few people who, having developed the signs of cancer in 1976, would still be alive to claim in 1996—20 years afterwards. That is of concern to me. I believe that until further research is done, it is not possible for us just to wipe out the chances of those people to make claims for compensation.

I am particularly concerned that there is an organisation of veterans who were exposed to the nuclear tests at Maralinga. Some of these tests were in fact very dirty nuclear tests—that is, they involved the destruction of plutonium devices at ground level and the detonation of nuclear weapons at close to ground level so that you create a large amount of radioactive dust, radioactive fallout. We still do not know the consequences of those tests.

BREAK.PARA: What I am saying, therefore, is that when we consider the rehabilitation of Maralinga we should also consider along with it the proper management of the human consequences of nuclear fallout and the proper management of those records.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the 21st report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation on The investment of Australia's superannuation savings , together with submissions and a record of the proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate my tabling speech in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
This is the twenty‐first report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation.

This report provides an overview and analysis of the legal, economic, and social issues associated with the investment of superannuation savings. As such it represents an audit of some of the current market‐place trends and policy developments in the area of superannuation investment.

Underlying its analysis was the Committee's recognition that the primary purpose of superannuation is to provide retirement income. The Committee was mindful that any changes to the superannuation system must reflect this fundamental principle.

The Committee considered the nature of investment generally and in relation to the trend toward globalisation. The report then examined the duties and obligations of trustees and the history behind the development of those duties and obligations. In this context the report raised the concept of socially responsible investment and looked at some American examples. The more controversial concept of directed investment was rejected by the Committee. The report briefly considers the question of fraud as the issue was raised in some of the submissions.

The report examined infrastructure investment and tax concessions. Evidence provided to the Committee suggested a degree of confusion regarding the intent and operation of these concessions. Accordingly the Committee has recommended that the relevant taxation provisions be clarified. The Committee noted the natural appeal that the long term nature of infrastructure might well have for superannuation funds.

The Committee also examined investment in small and medium sized businesses (SMEs) was examined in some detail. The report discusses some of the difficulties in matching the generally lower level of funding generally sought by SMEs, with the much larger amounts superannuation funds are seeking to invest. The Committee noted with approval the steps that are occurring in the market place to bring SMEs and superannuation savings together.

The Committee examined the relationship between housing and superannuation did not find a persuasive case for the draw down of superannuation savings for the purchase of a home. The report notes some difficulties which exist in the operation of the infrastructure bond provisions in relation to public sector housing initiatives.
Increasing mortgage securitisation is regarded favourably by the Committee, especially given the role of this process in lowering interest rates generally for housing.

The Institute of Actuaries of Australia defines short termism as `a preference for an investment policy which seeks to minimise short‐term fluctuations in the rate of return on assets'. Superannuation funds have consistently been criticised for this investment practice.

Although the Committee found that undue short termism can lead to problems for superannuation funds, it also discovered that there is an awareness among industry players of the dangers, and that the industry is taking steps to address this issue. The report recommends that the government should review and monitor superannuation policy and legislation to ensure the maximising of retirement incomes is not being unduly affected by short term investment considerations.

The final chapter of the report reflects the Committee's consideration of broader social objectives in relation to superannuation fund investment. An essential question implicit in the Committee's terms of reference was the compatibility of the furtherance of broader social objectives with the fundamental requirements on trustees flowing from the trust relationship and prudential control legislation.

The trust relationship is pivotal to our superannuation system. It has shaped its development to date, and has been its fundamental and defining characteristic. The Committee notes, however, the Budget announcement that a regime of retirement savings accounts is to be established outside the requirements of trust law and considers there is a need for Parliamentary oversight of such changes.

Throughout the report, the view taken by the Committee is that the primary aim of superannuation is to provide retirement income, and the law requires trustees to act at all times in the best interests of fund members. The furtherance of broader objectives, or socially responsible investment as it is sometimes called, is not necessarily incompatible with trustees' legal and fiduciary obligations.

For example, the Committee was told of a large industry fund which had a provision in its investment policy statement that, all things being equal in terms of returns and risks, trustees will prefer a project or investment which had job creation benefits.

With the increasing emphasis on greater choice, the report recognised the need of superannuation fund members to have more information to assist in making their long term investment decisions. Members need greater eduction generally about the long term nature of superannuation, and specifically about kinds of investments that are possible within the regulatory framework.

The Committee examined the view that Australia needs to develop a conscious national strategy to take advantage of the huge volume of superannuation assets in determining our social and economic future. As a result of the decline in public investment and trend toward privatisation, it has been argued that there is a need to harness superannuation for social and economic purposes.

Notwithstanding some of the attractions such a view offers, the Committee is unable to accede to it. There would be insufficient parliamentary support for such a major revision to our superannuation system, especially given the development in investment patterns and financial markets that the Committee identifies in its report. Again the basic role of superannuation savings in providing retirement incomes needs to be emphasised. The assets of superannuation funds should not be regarded as a public asset.

To the extent that people can self‐fund their retirement incomes, thereby reducing the pension burden on future taxpayers, and to the extent that increased domestic saving leads to higher levels of domestic investment, all Australians will benefit from the current superannuation system.

My thanks go to Bronwyn McNaughton who was the Committee Secretary responsible for the preparation of this report. I should add that Bronwyn has now gone to work in the superannuation industry after only a short time with the Committee. Her predecessor left to work in legal practice in the superannuation area and it seems our Committee is becoming highly efficient in preparing people for further employment in this field!
I commend the report to the Senate.

The Proceeds of Crime Amendment Bill 1996 forms part of my portfolio's significant contribution to the Government's task of achieving major savings in outlays.
The bill amends the Proceeds of Crime Act by providing for the transfer each year of the net balance of the Confiscated Assets Trust Fund to the Consolidated Revenue Fund.
The net balance will be calculated by deducting from the balance those payments that have to be made for statutory purposes.

Payments that have to be made for statutory purposes include a prescribed annual management fee, payments under the equitable sharing program to the States and Territories where the Commonwealth has been able to recover proceeds because of the significant contribution of a State or Territory law enforcement agency, and payments by way of restitution to innocent third parties or where quashing of a conviction causes discharge of a forfeiture order.

The bill also offers increased payments into the Confiscated Assets Trust Fund and subsequently into Consolidated Revenue by extending the present equitable sharing program to the international arena.

The proposed international sharing arrangement is intended to promote Australian law enforcement strategy by increasing the motivation of foreign countries to assist in recovering assets in their jurisdictions which are subject to forfeiture under Australian legislation.

The arrangement will authorise payment into the Confiscated Assets Trust Fund of payments made to Australia by a foreign country in recognition of assistance provided by Commonwealth law enforcement agencies; and it will give me the discretion to authorise payment to a foreign country where that country has made a significant contribution to the recovery of proceeds under a Commonwealth law.
Increasingly, Australia needs assistance from other countries in relation to the investigation of sophisticated organised crime.
The proposed sharing arrangement would provide an incentive to other countries to initiate or support investigations of Australian criminal activity.
Australia stands to benefit substantially from the arrangement, because the proposed sharing arrangement is likely to foster a net inflow of confiscated proceeds into Australia.
In order to be able to encourage and promote sharing with Australia of proceeds recovered by foreign countries, Australia must be able to reciprocate.

The arrangement is in addition to any other "sharing" of recovered proceeds which may apply when, under the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987, Australia is able to have its proceeds orders enforced in a foreign country and the proceeds repatriated to Australia, or to enforce a foreign country's proceeds orders in an Australian court and return the funds to that country.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
