TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call Senator Heffernan, I remind honourable senators that this is his first speech and I therefore ask that the usual courtesies be extended to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Heffernan, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam President, for the opportunity to make my first speech to this parliament on a day that, for me, combines family significance with political history. It was on this day 60 years ago that my mother, who is in the gallery there today, and my late father were married. Forty‐seven years ago on this day, the Menzies government was elected for what was to become a record term in government. I feel sure Sir Robert is here in spirit today, not for my speech but to follow the West Indies playing the Prime Minister's X1.

SPEECH.PARA: Today, I come to this place proud to represent my state of New South Wales as a Senator. I am aware of the privilege and great responsibility and I am grateful to my family, mentors and the Liberal Party for the opportunity.

I am proud to be a product of the New South Wales Division of the Liberal Party and honoured to have served it as President for the last three years. The Division has taken many difficult decisions in those years, decisions which have included performance assessment and enhancement by audit and, where necessary, candidate replacement. These measures, backed by a determined state executive, have delivered, on merit, to this the 38th federal parliament, a fresh team of young men and women to complement their more experienced colleagues.

A record 14 new Liberal members from New South Wales entered this parliament following the March election. The Liberal Party, without fuss or fanfare, and certainly without quotas or tokens, has led the way to deliver more women to parliament.

We are proud that our team, this parliament and our nation is led by a member of the New South Wales Division, John Howard. He is a man who has all the qualities of leadership that are best summed up in John Buchan's `Great Captains' from Homilies and Recreations. I quote:

We can make a catalogue of the moral qualities of the greatest captains but we cannot exhaust them. First there will be courage, not merely the physical kind, but the rarer thing, the moral courage which we call fortitude—the power of enduring when hope is gone. There must be the capacity for self‐sacrifice, the willingness to let worldly interests and even reputation and honour perish, if only the task be accomplished. The man who is concerned with his own prestige will never move mountains. There must be patience supreme patience under misunderstandings and set‐backs, and the muddles and interferences of others. There must be resili ence under defeat, a tough vitality and a manly optimism, which looks at the facts in all their bleakness and yet dares to be confident. There must be the sense of the eternal continuity of a great cause, so that failure and even death will not seem the end, and a man sees himself as only a part in a predestined purpose. It may not be for him to breach the fortress, but the breach will come. I add another quality . . . The greatest captains have laid their spell not only on the mind and spirit, but on the heart of their armies.
John Howard's battlers have long willed him to be Australia's Prime Minister, and I am proud to have been part of the army of Australians that created a new dawn on 2 March.

I am also mindful of the long and outstanding service to the people of New South Wales given by my predecessor Michael Baume. Michael was the member for Macarthur from 1975 to 1983 and a senator for New South Wales from 1985 to 1996. Michael has always been a loyal servant of the state of New South Wales and the Liberal Party.

The pig industry will regret Michael Baume's departure from his honorary position as biographer of the life and times of the slickest piggery proprietor the industry has ever known. Michael gave a new meaning to `pig ties' as the proprietor did to porkies. I wish Michael all the best in his position as Consul‐General in New York.

I am a proud son of Junee—they say that half of Junee is in the gallery today—a town of 4,000 people, situated midway between Sydney and Melbourne on the main southern line. Junee, along with Werris Creek in northern New South Wales, is one of the great rail towns and rail junctions of New South Wales. We have had to adapt to the changing technology and the paradox of productivity and employment. Junee now has a greatly reduced dependence on rail.

It was during my time as shire president that the shire council, backed by strong community support, convinced the Liberal state government to allow the development in Junee of a drought proof employer—a long stay institution which also enjoys a high occupancy rate. I refer to the first privately designed, constructed and managed correctional centre in New South Wales, built by Theiss Contractors and operated by Australian Correctional Management.

The Junee community, like most bush communities, considers blood to be thicker than water. We are proud of a long list of high achievers who were born and raised in our shire. To name just a few, we sent Laurie Daley to Canberra to add a touch of class to the Raiders, Bernie Fraser to the Treasury and the Reserve Bank, and Ian Pike to be Chief Magistrate in New South Wales.

Junee is also fortunate to be 20 minutes from the `place of many crows', the dynamic regional capital of the Murrumbidgee Valley, Wagga Wagga, also known as the `garden city of the south'. Wagga Wagga is the largest inland city in New South Wales and home to 57,000 people.

Some of Wagga Wagga's prominent institutions include the Charles Sturt University—with a campus of 10,000 students including 500 international students; its flagship courses include wine sciences and equine sciences—the RAAF base, which is the primary ground‐training base to all three services; and the Kapooka army base, which is the headquarters of the 1st recruit training battalion. By 1999, Wagga Wagga district will also have a naval communications base.

Several of Wagga's current home‐grown sporting heroes include the captain of Australia's cricket team, Mark Taylor, and his opening partner of 33 tests—sure to be back—Michael Slater. Included as well are the captains of both AFL grand final teams: Paul Kelly of the Sydney Swans, and Wayne Carey of North Melbourne. Beat that!

I come from a large family. My mother is one of 14, my father is one of eight, I am one of seven. My wife, Margaret, and I have four children. Our home is simple Irish with many bedrooms and little carpet. Since leaving Joey's—that great institution—in 1959, I have lived in a world where there are more stars at night, where sunset is a work of art, where you freeze in winter and cook in summer. It is an environment where we have learnt from the ancient skills of our indigenous people and from the recent lessons of land care that man is merely the custodian of the land and that planet survival demands a certain order of our water, land, plants and animals—an order which when respected will provide for man. It is a world where words are rarely wasted and hard work, individual endeavour, fortitude, favourable weather and commonsense are basic requirements for success.

I come to the Senate as the 16th Liberal Senator for New South Wales since the foundation of the Party in 1945. My initial observations in this place are that it needs more fresh air, it has many bookshelves whose books seem to be valued by the metre, words seem valued by time, many speeches are delivered to attentive walls, many conversations are ended by bells, and life is an endless meeting—and I would not miss it for quids.

However, I am mindful that the cost to family life of political commitment is both high and well documented. I would not be here without the help of my Sydney foster family, Bill and Trish McPhee, the support of my family and my hardworking wife, Margaret, and my children, Kate, Will, Ted and Harriet—all of whom have had to make considerable sacrifices. They have always displayed much understanding and given me great support through the inevitable highs and lows of family, farming and politics.

No-one really understands what they mean to their own parents till they have their own children. I am saddened that the tide of life sweeps that meaning away for many people. For me, there are no more important words than the words I use to end every conversation I have with my children. No matter how robust and energetic these conversations are—and they seem to get more vigorous and assertive as the family gets older—the conversation always ends with a reciprocated, `I love you.'

We people from rural and remote Australia are a friendly mob. I found during early morning walks in Sydney with friends that saying `G'day' to other early morning walkers often invoked alarm. Madam President, you will be pleased to know after a few days we always broke down the barrier, and we had them all saying `Hello.' I am now working on the shy passers‐by in this place.

BREAK.PARA: My public life began in 1981 when the local baker, the late Ted Benbow, encouraged me to run—successfully—for a local government position on the Junee Shire Council. Then, in 1985, along with Alby Shultz—g'day, Alby; he is now the indefatigable Liberal State member for Burrinjuck but was then the dynamic field officer for the New South Wales Division—Ted got me to join the Liberal Party.

I would not mind a bag of wheat for every time I have been asked, `Why are you interested in politics?' and `Why aren't you a member of the National Party?' Suffice to say, I have a strong view that the Liberal and National parties should recognise the changing demographics in Australia, end the ridiculous pretence of differing constituencies, set aside individual agendas and ego, and have the guts and determination to give up the horse and sulky logic and become one strong, united party.

A decision to merge the Liberal and National Parties would strengthen the political hand of rural Australia, do much to strengthen cooperation and interaction between city and country and would be the most strategic political decision taken in recent political history.

I joined the Liberal Party because it is best placed to represent all Australians. It is not dominated by sectional interests. It is owned by no one individual or group. It is a Party in which all members, whatever their station in life, can enjoy equal self-esteem. Unlike other parties which have to put up barriers to retain their constituency, we are about breaking down the barriers and uniting all Australians.

Australia has one of the lowest participation rates by the wider community in party politics. It would probably be fair to say most Australians have a low regard for politics and politicians. Most believe that individuals can make no difference. Many have given up. I believe we can all make a contribution to a better Australia.

My first awareness of the national interest occurred when, as a young boy in the late 1940s, I attended an Anzac ceremony with my Uncle Kevin. I still remember when the bugle sounded the last post tears came to his eyes, and I cried because he cried. Later I discovered they were tears from a Changi-Burma line prison survivor. I then learnt of the significance of my uncle's tears, of the sacrifices and atrocities of war and how prejudices and ego often cause conflict. So was born my instinct for the national interest—an instinct that is far stronger than any ego or personal agenda, an instinct that has served me well, especially during my three years as Liberal Party president in New South Wales.

Many times I have observed the capacity of all Australians to pull together during times of war and national disaster. Is it too much to ask of the beneficiaries, of such capacity, to pull together in times of peace for social justice and a fair go for every Australian? The great challenge of uniting Australia in these times of shrinking government resources includes the provision of services and infrastructure to those people who are the backbone of our primary industries and who live in rural, regional and remote areas to enable them to enjoy a lifestyle that does not deteriorate into an underclass.

Equal is the challenge in our towns and cities, where much of suburbia is filled with a generation of unemployed parents and children, isolated by poverty, with low self-esteem and a lifestyle where drugs and suicide are an everyday expectation and work is a faded Bob Hawke promise. These people need real jobs, not retraining for non-existent jobs.

No less is the challenge imposed on this generation of Australians by the centuries of misunderstanding and neglect of our indigenous people. We must provide for the return to our indigenous people of their self-esteem: built up over thousands of years by their majestic mastery of traditional living, land custodial skills and timeless culture; broken down in 200 years by the inevitable exploratory nature of man, the intrusiveness of his machines, the enticement of his money and the destructive onslaught of his social habits.

A paradigm shift is required and will only occur when provision is made for our indigenous people to progress, even in remote areas, from communal benefit to individual benefit; when access for all Australians to health, education and employment is not distorted by location or station in life; and when, regardless of race, creed and colour, we purge those leaders who believe all should be equal except the equalisers and who see the often generous funds of government as the opportunity for a feast on which to fatten their personal circumstances while neglecting the famine. Unfortunately, when these predators of the public purse turn on, Australians who would normally be concerned and supportive turn off.

I wish to pay tribute to our primary industries. Primary industry, which is generally carried on in rural, regional and remote Australia and includes fishing, farming, forestry and mining, continues to contribute 75 per cent of Australia's net external earnings. Our regional cities, towns and villages that support our fishermen, foresters, farmers and miners are a vital part of that contribution, as are our rural women.

Our rural women are often taken for granted. Many run the farm, more often the farmer. Rural women display greater patience, more resilience and are generally better educated than are rural men. `Marry a teacher or nurse and droughtproof the farm' is still a well-known bush convention. Rural women often have to contend with droving, drafting and old harvest trucks, yet find the time to do the books, do the washing and ironing, cook the meals, oversee the homework, school excursions and weekend sport, water the garden and look like a lady of leisure for church on Sunday. Our rural women deserve a medal for holding together the spirit of family farming.

Our farmers are an endangered species. Despite the declining numbers of farmers, now down to 120,000, and an increasing average age, now 53; despite the drift to the coast and the fact that more people live in the western suburbs of Sydney than all of rural Australia; despite the decline of farm employment from 27 per cent of total employment in the 1920s to three per cent today; and despite the relentless decline in terms of trade for agriculture, our farmers and the world's farmers have to feed an extra 90 million people every year.

We live in a world where 1.3 billion people lack regular access to fresh water, where 800 million people do not enjoy food security, where 185 million children suffer malnutrition and where 1 billion people have an income of no more than $1 a day. Population growth is wearing down Mother Earth and swallowing up our farming land and agricultural water resources. Twenty‐five per cent of the world's agricultural land is degraded and 25 per cent of the world's wild fisheries are overfished. If the world does not wake up, in 100 years there will be no tropical rainforest.

The loss of land from dryland agricultural production to urban development requires, in resource transfer terms, 1,000 tonnes of water to produce from irrigation 1 tonne of wheat. Many land scarce societies who face such transfers face the paradox of the reproductive rights of the current generation and the survival rights of the next generation.

The great challenge in feeding the world will be to produce enough food at a price that is affordable to all without destroying the environment. Rural, regional and remote Australia has taken up this challenge. We have adopted landcare and our farmers are bonded to the land, often in a similar way to the custodial and spiritual ways of our indigenous people. They have stuck through drought, fires and floods, through good times and bad, they compete in world markets corrupted by the US and European treasuries and in many years have accepted fresh air and freedom as their only income.

My tribute also extends to my bush companions, our indigenous people, who live in rural and remote Australia. I share their love of the land and their concern for the loss of their timeless culture. They, like myself, sleep many nights under the stars, understand the value of a campfire and can read Mother Nature, her seasons and warning signals. They, sadly, often live in a mire of low self-esteem, shunned by the passage of time and technology.

Professor Ian Ring, who published research this year on the health of our indigenous people in the cape, found no improvement in any major health indicator since 1976. On every indicator, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders are disadvantaged compared with non-indigenous Australians. Life expectancy is 15 to 20 years less for Aboriginal people, while infant mortality is three times higher. An Aboriginal baby born today has still, despite our best efforts, only a one in three chance of living to the age of 65.

For many years, try as many have, we have failed these people. They, like our jackeroos, drovers, shearers, shearer's cooks and all rural dwellers, are a precious part of Australia's culture. All these people need not feel isolated and forgotten. They will have a champion for their cause in me.

It has been easy for many Australians to stir, by fax, phone and emotion, the melting pot recently introduced to this parliament by an Independent member of the House of Representatives. That universally poisonous melting pot of candour, criticism, blissful ignorance, fear, poignant truth and racial undertones is not peculiar to Australia, but it has tempted many in the media to report that speech with glasshouse headlines which invoke basic territorial jealousies, tribal instincts and human inconsistencies—headlines which trigger the pollsters and cult figures but which blatantly ignore the issues that unite Australians and overlook the proven capacity of Australians to embrace our `fair go' ethic.

The strength in the fabric of Australian society has always been the woven cloth, never a single thread. Our woven cloth has always included some threads of individual failure, tragedy, injustice and intolerance. The same cloth held threads of success, fortitude, self-sacrifice and compassion. We should not allow the thread of discontent spun from one speech in this parliament to unravel the fabric of Australian society.

Social inequity and disadvantage cannot be simply identified and isolated on a map. It is not determined by birth, bound by creed or colour, nor solved by worldwide days of recognition. Madam President, visiting Australia's disadvantaged by airconditioned car or bus or through the eye of the TV news is a comfortable First World response but no solution. Providing a real world solution will require Australians from all walks of life rolling up their sleeves and opening up their hearts.

I invite all concerned Australians to answer a call of feet, hands, hearts and means to establish a care corp—volunteers whose sole task would be to identify the priorities of disadvantage within Australia and act to alleviate them. By giving up a week of their time or a few days pay, not once but year after year, to marshall the resources of both government and the able in our community to overcome the plight of the most disadvantaged and needy in our society.

Our Governor-General, Sir William Deane, has recognised the collective plight of our disadvantaged as the most important problem facing our nation. If we can maintain the volunteer ethic in areas as diverse as firefighting, Meals on Wheels and international aid, then surely we can provide volunteer supervision and target community ownership of programs to rebuild self-esteem and refurbish essential services to our disadvantage.

Only a strong economy will fund from income the compassionate side of government, `the true measure of good government'. Bold initiatives will produce a strong economy, real jobs and real wealth. Australia is ready for an era of bold initiatives, an era of national savings and real wealth creation. Like the Snowy Mountain scheme of the 20th century, we need a plan for the 21st century—a plan which will bring cohesion and long-term benefit to all.

Our plan should include a very fast train which adopts an inland route and has passenger and freight capacity and time lines to link our capital cities. The VFT will break down the barrier between city and country, curb the environmentally destructive urban sprawl, open up development corridors for the next 100 years and be the bridge to the 21st century. It will take Australia from a country retiring to the coast, living on welfare and resting on its laurels to a new frontier for development with job opportunities and excitement.

We should also harness some of the millions of megalitres of fresh water that flows annually into our northern tropical seas. This water resource can be used to open up some of the last tracts of virgin farming land available in the world. Such a plan would recognise that in a world of shrinking land, mineral and water resources Australia has much to offer. It would also allow many remote communities, both black and white, a lifeline to higher self-esteem and a train ride to better health and education facilities and employment opportunities.

Our plan should also include research and development to allow the construction of mass transit systems, a vital strategy to meet Australia's commitment to reduction in greenhouse gases and addressing the looming fossil fuel crisis. Why can't we also develop technology to recycle the millions of megalitres of sewage polluting our seas and break the nexus of a throwaway society and a mountain of garbage?

For my own state of New South Wales, the development of an inland international air freight terminal would be a catalyst to restructure and vertically integrate the Murray-Darling farm enterprise and provide a long-term solution to salinity and degradation by water and land management practices. With the added value of workplace reform it would allow Murray-Darling farmers to competitively enter Asian supermarkets as fresh food suppliers to three billion people.

Madam President, the paradox and urban consolidation and urban sprawl, public and private transport, productivity employment, the myriad of environmental issues, clean air, fresh water—we buy fresh water now; will we eventually have to buy clean air?—are not some trendy `Greens' issues; they are our issues. They are planet survival issues which will not be solved by lobby groups, radical political agendas or single issue political parties. These issues will only be solved by government achieving interaction and understanding between city and council, between the various competing energies and agendas and between the producers and the users.

In recent years, Australian taxpayers have remained largely unaware yet committed to subsidising from future tax revenue $120 billion worth of unfunded state and federal public sector superannuation. We have tolerated a public purse which has allowed rights to overpower responsibilities and build in billion dollar rorts; an archaic tax system that taxes battlers and the thrifty, yet allows taxable profits in key industries to be exported by foreign owned and vertically integrated companies that use transfer pricing; and a 13-year fire sale of Australian equity in key export industries.

We have allowed our agricultural industries to have their disease free status and marketing edge threatened by political agendas and world trade predators. We have ignored the development of our national infrastructure, yet allowed Australian superannuation savings to develop foreign owned offshore infrastructure. We have largely ignored the vast underdeveloped water, land and mineral resources of Australia's far north. Is it any wonder we cannot fund hospitals, schools or house the homeless?

Who can fix all of this? We in this chamber can. We can ensure our children and future generations inherit from us a social, economic and environmental climate that is safe and secure, that Australia remains a great place to raise a family, breathe fresh air and drink clean water.

Madam President, every time I hear the bugle sound the last post, I am reminded that I belong to a generation that has never been to war, has taken much and given little. I am reminded that the debt we all owe to earlier generations of Australians cannot be repaid but merely serviced.

My aspirations are bound by the honour boards of past campaigns in both war and peace. My commitment is to reward the individual, unburden the dependent and protect the vulnerable. My hope is that in walking the tightrope between rights and responsibilities the balance will always be maintained in Australia by the peaceful democratic processes of our parliament.

My dream is that on the day of my last speech in this chamber I will be able to say that I have served in a parliament whose members have all put the nation's interests ahead of their own; a parliament which has robustly discarded as un‐Australian the morays of the eighties and its legacy of greed, corruption and debt; a parliament which has promoted a fair go for all as the spirit of Australia; a parliament which has delivered the opportunity for all Australians to enjoy independence of means and mind; and, finally, that my contribution in this place will be judged by my fellow Australians as worthwhile. My only wish then will be that God allows me to return with my family to the peace and tranquillity of the bush. Thank you very much.

TREASURER
Parliament House
Canberra ACT 2600
3 December 1996
Senator Brian Harradine
Senator for Tasmania
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Harradine

I refer to your letter of 2 September 1996 to Senator Alston in which you outline your reservations about the partial sale of Telstra. As foreshadowed by Senator Alston in his letter to you of 21 November 1996, I am responding to the technical issues raised in your letter.

At the outset, I note the importance of market signals in applying pressure for continuous improvement in the management of public sector trading enterprises such as Telstra. The partial sale of Telstra will significantly assist in achieving that goal.

Your letter raises an alternative financing option to the partial sale. This alternative option has been the subject of careful and detailed consideration by the Government. Schemes such as the one proposed by you have received serious consideration from the Government as they have been put to the Senate Inquiry into Telstra.

The model you suggest envisages Telstra issuing $8 billion in redeemable preference shares, then making this amount available to the Government through a partial `buy-back' of existing Commonwealth shares in Telstra. Telstra would be required to pay a 9 per cent annual return to investors for a 15 year period, at which time shares could be redeemed at the original $1 issue price. That is, your proposal would have very similar characteristics to Telstra issuing $8 billion in debt.

An issue of this nature would be without precedent in Australia. In fact, market analysts advise that it is highly questionable whether Australian and international markets would be sufficiently receptive to raise $8 billion from such a security. For this reason alone, it is doubtful that an issue of redeemable preference shares would return to the Commonwealth the equivalent proceeds of an ordinary share issue.

Even if such a raising was possible, it would have the effect of significantly constraining Telstra's financial capacity as it would be required to maintain existing operational levels while at the same time servicing a substantial additional liability but without the corresponding asset base which would be transferred to the Commonwealth. In raising the company's debt to equity ratio from 31 per cent to approximately 70 per cent, thus placing Telstra at the lower end of its international peer comparison range, the proposal would be likely to be viewed negatively by commercial ratings agencies and may lead to a significant drop in Telstra's credit rating. This would have the potential to compromise the company's future financing and operating flexibility.

It also needs to be borne in mind that the cost of borrowing envisaged by the proposal would be above the Commonwealth's current borrowing costs. As a result, the ongoing cost of servicing the debt raised by Telstra through the redeemable shares would be higher than the ongoing costs of the same value of sovereign debt to be retired with the proceeds. Furthermore, as the proposal would effectively represent a transfer of debt liability from the Government to Telstra, it would not permit a reduction in overall public sector debt levels as is envisaged by the partial sale process.

Your proposal also raises some fundamental taxation issues. You are probably aware that the issue of attaching franked dividend income to debt-like instruments has received considerable attention by government and the tax administration since the introduction of the imputation arrangements in the mid 1980s.

A proliferation of tax financing schemes led to the enactment of specific anti-avoidance provisions designed to prohibit the transfer of franking credits and other tax benefits by dividends which could reasonably be regarded as equivalent to the payment of interest on a loan.

The particular arrangement you describe would be likely to be caught by these provisions. The legislative amendments required to allow the franking of `debt dividends' would have wider application than to Telstra with consequent effects on the integrity of the tax system and the revenue.

I should also mention that the nature of imputation precludes the franking of (deductible) interest. Imputation was introduced in order to remove the effect of income being taxed in the hands of a company as profits and being taxed again in the hands of its shareholders when distributed by way of dividend. The relevant income is distributed out of a company's earnings after obligations, such as interest payments, are met. Payments of deductible interest do not distribute taxable income of the company and should not receive the benefit of imputation credits. Allowing such payments to be franked would not have the effect of relieving double taxation but of sheltering from tax otherwise taxable income.

Whilst on the question of imputation arrangements, I note your suggestion that publicly owned companies operate at a competitive disadvantage because their shareholder governments cannot utilise any franking credits which they may accumulate. If there is a disadvantage it is not to the company: its tax liability is the same whether its shareholders are taxed at normal tax rates, reduced tax rates, or are exempt.

The general question of State-owned enterprises is dealt with by the Statement of Policy Intent on the taxation treatment of government trading enterprises, agreed at the 1994 Premiers' Conference; otherwise the basis for the imputation arrangements is that there should not be double taxation on that part of a company's profits that is passed to shareholders by way of dividend. Having regard to the fact that governments do not pay tax the issue of double taxation does not arise.

Your proposal also raises a potential difficulty with the Corporations Law under which Telstra operates. This relates to that aspect which would see a capital sum paid to the government for the explicit purpose of financing the Heritage Trust. Section 162 of the Corporations Law prohibits a company from undertaking an act other than in pursuance of its objectives. With such clear intention attached to the arrangement proposed it would be difficult to argue that the funds transferred to the Commonwealth were for Telstra's business purposes. The Government could not contemplate an arrangement which breached the Corporations Law in any way.
I trust the above comments serve to explain why the Government believes that the partial privatisation route remains the most appropriate course to achieving its policy goals.

Senator Alston is aware of the contents of this letter, and the reasons it discloses for the Government's decision to follow the partial privatisation route. However he has indicated that he would be happy to address other aspects of your letter should you require that.
Yours sincerely
(Sgd) PETER COSTELLO
TELSTRA: REDEEMABLE PREFERENCE SHARES
Analysis of Treasury arguments contained in the Treasurer's letter of 3 December 1996
Page 1, Para 2

"I note the importance of market signals in applying pressure for continuous improvement in the management of public sector trading enterprises such as Telstra. The partial sale of Telstra will significantly assist in achieving that goal."

This ignores the question of a natural monopoly. Markets are concerned about return on investment. Increased returns on investment may indicate either more intensive exploitation of a natural monopoly (which represents a tax on other businesses and consumers with all its adverse effects) or an improvement in management efficiency (which is wholly desirable).

To the extent that profits on Telstra's natural monopoly assets did represent a tax on users, gains on portfolio investments in Telstra would be offset by losses on shares in other businesses faced with higher charges against their profits.

In any case, participating preference shares where the dividend varies with the ordinary dividend do have a fluctuating market value and do give market signals as to perceptions of management efficiency in so far as that contributes to increased profitability. The United States literature confirms this: see, for example, Hu New Financial Products, the Modern Process of Financial Innovation, and the Puzzle of Shareholder Welfare (1991) 69 Texas Law Review 1273.
Page 1, Para 4

"Telstra would be required to pay a 9 per cent annual return to investors for a 15 year period, at which time shares could be redeemed at the original $1 issue price. That is, your proposal would have very similar characteristics to Telstra issuing $8 billion in debt."

The example of a 9 per cent fixed dividend preference share for 15 years was an example only, as previously indicated. In fact the coupon yield would be likely to be substantially less, as indicated by current stock market yields and taking into account the imputation credits likely to be available. Redemption need not be mandatory but optional at Telstra's wish. There are a wide range of options for the design of redeemable preference shares ranging from fixed coupon cumulative preference shares the redemption of which is mandatory to participating non‐cumulative preference shares the redemption of which is optional at the instance of Telstra. It is therefore not correct in terms of either legal or economic analysis to say that the proposal to raise finance by way of redeemable preference shares is similar to raising $8 billion in debt.
Page 1, Para 5
"An issue of this nature would be without precedent in Australia."

The proposed sale of Telstra is an unusual event. There are plenty of precedents for the issue of redeemable preference shares. Whether the shares are ordinary shares or preference shares the size of the float will be equally unprecedented.
"In fact, market analysts advise that it is highly questionable whether Australian and international markets would be sufficiently receptive to raise $8 billion from such a security."

As to the perceptions of market analysts there is no signed supporting documentation attached to the Treasurer's letter. Who are these analysts? Where are their experts' reports? Generally the market is willing to buy any security—it is all a question of portfolio preference and pricing, weighing up the outlay versus the return. Given the unprecedented size of the proposed transaction, it would be reasonable to expect that Parliament have the benefit of fully reasoned experts' opinions, and valuation analyses of different options for raising funds from Telstra. The extreme demand Australian investors have for fixed interest paper (SBC estimates a $20 billion shortfall in suitable domestic paper per annum) would mean that even a non-participating redeemable preference share would be highly attractive.
". . . it is doubtful that an issue of redeemable preference shares would return to the Commonwealth the equivalent proceeds of an ordinary share issue."

No one has ever suggested that redeemable preference shares are worth the equivalent of ordinary shares. The question is whether redeemable preference shares can efficiently raise $8 billion for the Commonwealth while retaining the Commonwealth's underlying rights to Telstra's natural monopoly assets. Ordinary shares locked into a one third minority may have to be offered at a greater discount to underlying value than redeemable preference shares. The question is not just how much money the Commonwealth gets in but what value it is parting with in return for its money. A freehold sale of land will always bring in more money than the sale of a 30 year leasehold of the same property but a leasehold sale may better preserve the wealth of the seller.
Page 1, Para 6

". . . it [Telstra] would be required to maintain existing operational levels while at the same time servicing a substantial additional liability but without the corresponding asset base which would be transferred to the Commonwealth."

Servicing dividends on participating non-cumulative preference shares need involve no more additional liability than servicing dividends on ordinary shares. Telstra's asset base would be unchanged as $8 billion would come in as capital from preference shareholders to finance the buy back of $8 billion worth of ordinary shares from the Commonwealth.
"In raising the company's debt to equity ratio from 31 per cent to approximately 70 per cent. . . "

The debt to equity analysis rests on the fallacious assumption that all preference shares are equivalent to debt. It assumes that any preference share would have a fixed coupon and redemption would be mandatory. The arguments advanced show no evidence of serious consideration of participating, non-cumulative or optional redemption preference shares. Hybrid equity of this sort is not even innovative, any more, in the United States market. A pro-business government should be enthused over new vehicles to attract domestic savings.
Page 2, Para 1
". . . the cost of borrowing envisaged by the proposal would be above the Commonwealth `s current borrowing costs."

As noted above, one would expect the yield on preference shares to be less than 9 per cent on current market conditions and be below Commonwealth borrowing costs because of the availability of imputation credits.

". . . the ongoing cost of servicing the debt raised by Telstra through redeemable shares would be higher. . . the proposal would effectively represent a transfer of debt liability from the Government to Telstra."
This also rests on the fallacy that preference shares are necessarily equivalent to debt.
Page 2, Para 4

"The particular arrangement you describe would be likely to be caught by these provisions. The legislative amendments required to allow the franking of `debt dividends' would have wider application than to Telstra with consequent effects on the integrity of the tax system and the revenue."
Treasury has a tendency to describe as "tax avoidance" anything which reduces the revenue even if it is a long established commercial practice such as the issue of redeemable preference shares.

Apparently, the Treasury took the view that redeemable preference shares are essentially a tax avoidance device and wished to eliminate them through section 46D. This policy view may be disputed, since redeemable preference shares were used for decades before income tax was imposed. Further, in the absence of a full integration system of company tax which would impute losses directly to shareholders, arrangements to use up company tax losses are necessarily either non-neutral or a form of tax avoidance. Indeed the Asprey Committee in 1975 recommended carry back of losses and flow through of losses for small companies!

The Treasury's attempt to distinguish between ordinary dividends and debt dividends was essentially misconceived. In Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No 5) of December 1989, Treasury introduced a severe tax penalty widely thought (not always correctly) to outlaw redeemable preference shares. If a company paid what Treasury described as a "debt dividend" (not clearly defined) not only did the dividend lose any imputation credits but the dividend was taxable in the hands of the recipient while the company was denied a tax deduction for the "debt dividend".

It is not clear that redeemable preference shares are necessarily caught or should be caught by the provisions relating to so-called "debt dividends". Treasury-speak about the "integrity of the tax system" is nonsense when it is realised that the tax system is creating unjustified distortions against flexible financing instruments for companies and generating more fragility in the corporate sector when recessions come. Removal of tax distortions was one of the key themes of the FitzGerald report on National Saving. Denial of imputation credits to capital protected equity is a Luddite response to pro-savings financial innovation. It would be absurd to allow pseudo‐arguments about the so-called "integrity of the tax system" (which rest on ignorance of basic tax theory) to prevent serious consideration about the most advantageous way for Parliament to ensure the public receives the greatest benefit from its Telstra assets.
Page 2, Para 5

". . . the nature of imputation precludes the franking of (deductible) interest. . . Payments of deductible interest do not distribute taxable income of the company and should not receive the benefit of imputation credits."

Irrelevant—as dividends on preference shares are not interest payments. One may also note that section 46D actually imposes double taxation because franking credits are denied to so-called "debt dividends" yet these payments are not deductible. With such a lack of consistency it is hard to take Treasury seriously.
Page 2, Para 6
"If there is a disadvantage it is not to the company. . . "

Because Government owned companies cannot raise capital from taxpayers who can use franking credits they are at a competitive disadvantage in terms of a lack of flexibility as between debt and equity capital raising. The Industry Commission recognised in its inquiry into Charitable Organisations in Australia (Report No. 45, 16 June 1995, p.318) that the imputation system does bias the investment decisions of tax exempt bodies which cannot receive refunds of imputation credits for company tax levied on their portion of taxed company income. The Treasury has refused to even look at the Industry Commission's suggestion.
Page 2, Para 7

". . . the basis for the imputation arrangements is that there should not be double taxation on that part of a company's profits that is passed to shareholders by way of dividend. Having regard to the fact that governments do not pay tax the issue of double taxation does not arise."

The basis for the imputation arrangements is that company income should be imputed to shareholders and they should get credit for the tax paid by the company on their portion of the company's income. Given that the logic of imputation is that company tax is essentially a withholding tax paid by the company on behalf of the shareholders, there is no logical reason why imputation credits should not be refundable in cash as is the case with excess PAYE instalments. As the Treasury (1986) has pointed out in Some Economic Implications of Takeovers Treasury Economic Paper No. 12, AGPS Canberra, has pointed out, the logical imputation of full imputation is that "there would be no company tax as such on company income but, as a withholding arrangement companies would make a tax payment which was deemed to be a prepayment of personal tax on the share of total company income in which its shareholder had an interest." Yet Treasury shrinks from its own logic and denies shareholders cash refunds.
Page 2, Para 8

"Your proposal also raises a potential difficulty with the Corporations Law under which Telstra operates. This relates to that aspect which would see a capital sum paid to the government for the explicit purpose of financing the Heritage Trust. Section 162 of the Corporations Law prohibits a company from undertaking an act other than in pursuance of its objectives. With such clear intention attached to the arrangement proposed it would be difficult to argue that the funds transferred to the Commonwealth were for Telstra's business purposes. The Government could not contemplate an arrangement which breached the Corporations Law in any way."

While it is gratifying that the Government would not contemplate breaching the Corporations Law, this paragraph appears to involve some basic ignorance on the part of the Treasury Department of the Corporations Law which has been recently transferred to its administration. The Treasury seems not to understand that section 162 relates to the abolition of the ultra vires doctrine. The power to buy back shares is conferred by the Corporations Law and shareholders are free under section 117 to dispense with an objects clause in any case.

Section 162(2)(b) simply provides that where the memorandum of a company contains a provision stating the objects of the company and the company does an act other than in pursuance of those objects then the company contravenes the sub-section. However there is no legal requirement for a company to have an objects clause at all—nor has there been any such requirement since 1 January 1984.
Even where there is an objects clause, it is always open to the shareholders to amend the company's objects clause by following the procedures set out in sections 171 and 172.

It is a fantastical proposition to suggest that the use of a buy back procedure specifically sanctioned by Division 4B of the Corporations Law must necessarily involve a breach of that same law if the shareholders receiving the money for the shares bought back do not use that money for the purposes of the company.

If such a proposition were correct, Parliament is entitled to advice as to why other buy-backs (e.g. Westpac, Commonwealth Bank, National Australia Bank) are not in breach of the Corporations Law. It would be interesting to have a legal opinion from the Solicitor-General on the Treasury's interpretation of section 162.
General Observations

It is a matter of concern that a great department of State should have provided its Minister with advice which evidences a basic lack of understanding of the laws placed under its administration. This is especially a concern where those laws relate to matters as important as taxation and the governance of companies. In such a situation the Government and the Board of Telstra are placed in the difficult position of being forced to seek further advice before being able to consider properly and resolve alternative options for raising $8 billion from the Commonwealth's Telstra assets.

In the face of such defective official Treasury advice, the Government may well become embarrassed by the lack of serious Departmental expertise, the business community alarmed by the anti-business tax ideology of the Treasury, and the general public gravely concerned about whether Treasury can secure the best value from public assets.

The business community, alarmed by the anti-business tax ideology of the Treasury, and the general public are gravely concerned about whether Treasury can secure the best value from public assets.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

Indeed, it will be very odd when, under the structure that the minister has put forward, the minority shareholders will be able to start dictating, under the Corporations Act, to the majority shareholders—the Australian people—the best outcomes to maximise the profit, against the interests of the majority. For example, in an estimates hearing recently, we had confirmation from Telstra that, when they get rid of 22,000 workers, the bottom line profit to Telstra will be increased by $600 million per annum.

I would imagine that the private shareholders—the directors—involved in that third will say, `We want that redistributed to dividends,' to maximise their return on their investment. That is what they would do. It is not unnatural. It would be a perfectly natural response for minority shareholders to get back as quickly as possible through dividends the money on their investment. But that may not be in the best national interest of Australia, for the Australian community.

As the AIDC example showed, the minority will hold the majority to ransom under Corporations Law. Unless the power of the minister to direct is put back into this legislation, we will have the worst outcome—even worse than it is now. It may be one‐third privatisation but, in effect, full control will be given to the private sector, to the private shareholders. That is what is going to happen if we do not put this power back in.

I draw to the attention of the minister, who will strongly oppose this, that in only the last few days the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) said in relation to legislation to establish an employment agency run by the private sector, the Public Employment Placement Enterprise Ltd, `We will maintain the power of the minister to direct.' I draw attachment 1 of the statement to the attention of the committee, particularly Senators Colston and Harradine. If Senator Vanstone believes she should have that power in relation to that enterprise, why should it not apply to Telstra? Attachment 1 states:

It will also be open to the minister to direct the provision by the company, at reasonable cost, of employment services in the public interest. This will ensure that the government has the capacity to cover any situation where employment services need to be delivered in a location but where the market has not responded in the tender process and no other arrangements are available.

That is what Senator Vanstone said. She is not exactly noted for an impeccable performance as a minister in this area over the last nine months. She has woken up. She wants protection in the national interest. Even though this is a fully privatised operation, she wants to hold the power of the minister to direct, to get outcomes in the national interest. If it is good enough for Senator Vanstone and that new private enterprise arrangement, it ought to be good enough for the minister to retain the power to direct in the case of Telstra.

I say to Senators Harradine and Colston: you have reached arrangements on issues relating to employment and provision of services, particularly to regional Australia. If this power of the minister to direct is not maintained, you are relying on extraordinary good faith—forever and a day. The one thing you will be able to do to meet your commitments as far as you see them is to know that the minister has the power to direct. You will be able to go to the minister and say, `This deal is not being met.' If you let this provision go through as is, and the minister says, `But the board of Telstra said something different and I cannot do anything about it,' the minister will be dead right. But, if you have this power to direct put back in, you will have some negotiating power with him.

Even though the minister will say that the power to direct has not been used since Telstra became a GBE, we all know that the fact it is there has an influence on the board and in the informal discussions. The minister, in his own statement issued last week, headed `Telstra's presence in Tasmania and Queensland', stated:
Over the past few weeks I have been working with Telstra to identify some of the implications of their current three-year business plan for Tasmania and Queensland.

If they do not agree to have talks with him, they all know that he can actually direct them. Remove that power to direct, and there will be no talks. It just will not happen. Once that symbol of ministerial power is removed, the informal discussions will stop. I believe that is the most pressing issue we are now faced with.

Do we want a Telstra acting totally in the commercial interest at the behest of the minority shareholders, a la what happened with the AIDC? The way they acted was a considerable embarrassment and it affected the program of the government accordingly because they could threaten to sue. Do we want the same to happen with Telstra? Of course we do not.

There will be issues from time to time over the next few years as we want to develop, as Senator Harradine wants for Tasmania, the high quality telecommunications system and broadband services. Senator Alston has said that there are no plans by either Telstra or Optus to roll out broadband services in Hobart in the foreseeable future—none whatsoever.

In the end, if we want it for Tasmania then at least we can get it by the minister directing Telstra to do it, so that some of the $20 billion capital works program of Telstra over the next five years will be spent in Tasmania or other regional areas. That will be to make sure that we have a telecommunications network throughout Australia to which all Australians have equal and equitable access. We in the opposition make no bones about it: we believe this power is there for the public good.

Even if Telstra is privatised by a third, we give notice here and now that, if this power to direct is taken out, when we get back into government we will take every action possible to restore this power to the act. We say that now so that potential investors do not go around the place saying that they have been ambushed about this. We will take every possible action to restore this to the act if it is taken out during this process. We think it is much better in the national interest that this bill be amended now to maintain the power to direct so that we do not have to go through that process and so that all investors know what they are buying with Telstra.

These investors will know that the power to direct is in the act and that if they try to abuse the power of Telstra, this natural monopoly that Senator Harradine so aptly describes, the minister's power to direct will be able to be used for the benefit of the national interest, not for the benefit of minority shareholders interested in only one thing—profit—irrespective of Australia's national interest. Of course, a third of the third will be foreign investors. They have only one absolute interest—profit. They will not be interested in serving all Australians. They will not be interested in jobs in regional Queensland or southern Tasmania or anywhere else.

We believe that the issue of the minister's power to direct is fundamental. Being a shareholder representing 66⅔ per cent and then giving up and saying that you have got no power at all, that you cannot direct your own directors because they will then be taken on by the minority and the minority will sue accordingly, really is abdication by the government against the national interest.

I say quite bluntly that I appeal to Senator Harradine and Senator Colston on this particular measure to support this in the national interest and also in the very narrow view of ensuring that they have got the leverage to deliver the arrangements they have made by the minister still being able to direct Telstra. This is a fundamentally important issue and our amendment is to restore that power, as it should be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not spoken at any great length in the committee stage of the Telstra (Dilution of Public Ownership) Bill 1996, but I do want to speak on this amendment. SPEECH.PARA: During my period, the cabinet decided to sell the lot of the AIDC. What happened then was that we found the holder of the majority shareholding in the public interest could not get access to the documents of the AIDC for the very good reason that the rights of minority shareholders under Australian corporate law are protected. That is a very good principle.

It is a principle that arose because in the eighties the corporate cowboys of this country flogged off corporate entities left, right and centre, irrespective of the rights of the minorities. For example, Alan Bond is on charges in Perth at the moment. The hour after the Bond Corporation took over Bell Resources, they went in and asked Bell Resources to write a cheque for $1.2 billion and hand it to the Bond Corporation, which they did. So when I, as minister, holding about 82 per cent of the shares of the AIDC, wanted to conduct a due diligence study in order to ready the AIDC for the sale of the other 82 per cent, I could not. What we then did was buy back the minority shareholding. You would think that an 82 per cent shareholder would be able to influence a board decision. It cannot. It cannot in that sense, and we could not. I think it is absolutely essential for an entity like Telstra to have the reserve powers of ministerial authority. It is absolutely essential.

The outgoing Managing Director of the AIDC claimed a retirement package and a salary package over $1 million. I was questioned in this chamber as to how I, as a responsible minister, could allow salary enhancements of that order to go on when the government was preaching wage restraint to ordinary Australians. I seriously say to the government, and not just to the Independents on whose swing vote this may revolve, that once you sell a minority shareholding of an agency such as this, you automatically introduce into that agency the desire for it to make a profit and to reward those people who have bought those shares as an investment. That is in contradistinction to the service obligation that the organisation has and which we as a government will insist on.

BREAK.PARA: But under corporate law the rights of those minority shareholders are protected and they can insist too, with considerable force, that their interest has to be met. This sounds a bit like the immovable object meeting the irresistible force. What happens in those circumstances is that ways are found around it. Unless there is the reserve power of the government or the strong presence of the government, then you will find that all sorts of things that are not in your interest as a government or as a minority shareholder occur.

If I were a cynical person, I would not tell you this. Being a cynic, I would sit back and allow you to be embarrassed in that way and then have a go at the whole idea of privatisation because of that embarrassment. If anyone is in any doubt about anything I say, do not believe me but go back and look at the circumstances of the AIDC. At that time the Department of Finance said to us, `Well, look, we want to float the AIDC, but we do not want the government to have a controlling interest or a golden share'—as the debate was at that time—`because that may well affect the price we get at the float.' That is true, it may well affect it. Some investors will be adverse to that proposition and not want to invest if they think that they, as investors and shareholders, cannot help form the policy directions of this organisation in certain areas.

That is a risk that you take when you part‐privatise; that is a risk that you have to accept when you part‐privatise. TALK.START.PARA: —Or part-dead.

BREAK.PARA: I say to all the other senators in this chamber: I make these remarks, talking from bitter experience in my former ministerial days of what an actual case study meant in terms of this situation. TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I will deal with Senator Cook's point. The bill includes specific provisions to overcome any problems that were reportedly experienced with the AIDC in relation to the provision of information to the Commonwealth. It is a pity that you did not know this before you came in.

SPEECH.PARA: New sections 8AD and 8AI of the Telstra Corporation Act would impose reporting obligations on Telstra and ensure that the exclusive provision of this oversight information to the Commonwealth does not breach the Corporations Law. New sections 8AQ and 8AR oblige Telstra to assist the Commonwealth in the conduct of a Telstra sales scheme and ensure that the provision of relevant information to the Commonwealth for the purposes of the sale of Telstra shares does not breach the Corporations Law. In the case where Telstra shares were sold in more than one tranche, these provisions will remove any argument that existing minority shareholders in Telstra are being unfairly treated by the exclusive provision of information to the Commonwealth.

It is very important to understand what occurs at the present time. Since Telstra became a government business enterprise in 1991, it has been obliged by the Corporations Law, governed by the Corporations Law, to act in the best interests of the company and its shareholders. That does not allow the board to act uncommercially, nor has any government sought to request it to act uncommercially. As we have established, there have been no directions given under this power. In other words, there has been an acceptance since 1991 that the company ought to act commercially. To the extent that you want to impose any social obligations over and above the company, you do that by legislation.

That is the scheme that governs all government business enterprises. That is the concept of a community service obligation. You impose on a company an obligation to do something that it would not otherwise do. You have provisions in relation to untimed local calls because, otherwise, the company would presumably want to act commercially and charge on a timed local calls basis. You impose price caps because you take the view that it is important to ensure that the benefits of new technology and productivity gains are passed on to consumers.

So in a number of instances, the parliament recognises that to allow a company to act commercially will not always deliver social outcomes that the parliament regards as important. The parliament can then step in and take action, as we are doing in relation to the regional telecommunications infrastructure fund. In other words, it is a reasonable proposition to assume that neither Telstra nor any other carrier or perhaps service provider would be likely to provide services in rural and remote areas to the extent that some people might desire.

But there is the world of difference between making a budget allocation providing funds to ensure that that is done in a proper and transparent manner so that everyone understands how it is occurring and, on the other hand, having an arrangement whereby you can ring up the company surreptitiously—and Senator Schacht says that you do not have to do it by giving an official direction; you simply lean on them. What that does is provide endless opportunities for political interference to achieve political objectives. In other words, just for example—

TALK.START.PARA: —This is what you said last week. It is in the statement.

—If you read the statement you will find that I simply relayed concerns and I am reporting there on Telstra's decisions consistent with its corporate plan. But what you are talking about is having the ability to somehow tell Telstra to do things that it would not otherwise do. If that is not a recipe for political interference, I do not know what is.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not very difficult to imagine a situation where you are in government, you have a couple of seats which you want particular facilities delivered to, Telstra says, `It's not economic for us to do it,' and you say, `But I want you to do it and I've got the power to direct you to do it.' What sort of basis for decision making is that? The appropriate way to do it, if you take the view that assistance ought to be provided in those electorates, is for the parliament to appropriate those funds. If it is a deserving cause, it deserves to be funded properly. But once you are interfering with the commercial operations of a company—

TALK.START.PARA: —You own two‐thirds of it, Richard. You are the two-thirds shareholder.

—Being a two-thirds shareholder has nothing to do with whether or not the company ought to act commercially or whether the directors ought to act in the best interests of the shareholders. They will do that and continue to do it.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no basis for the suggestion, which I think was made by Senator Margetts, that somehow the Gambotto decision will mean that the tail is wagging the dog—the government will be able to exercise its power as a majority shareholder because it will have two‐thirds of the shares. There are no provisions in the Corporations Law or any court decisions which put minority shareholders in such a privileged position.

The Gambotto case dealt with the situation where the articles of a company had been changed by the majority shareholder to expropriate shares held by minority shareholders. The High Court's decision in that case confirmed that a majority shareholder must act in the interests of the company as a whole, not just promote its own interests, and must not act in a manner which treats minority shareholders unfairly. The government accepts that it should not treat minority shareholders in Telstra unfairly.

The bill, therefore, overrides the Corporations Law only to facilitate the sale process and to ensure that Telstra is properly accountable to parliament. In other words, there has always been a doctrine of law that protects minority interest from oppression. You cannot say, `Simply because I've got the numbers on the board, I can do what I like. I'll make decisions in my interest and to hell with the minorities.' That is not the law, nor should it be. That is simply what the Gambotto case reinforced. But to suggest that somehow Telstra is the plaything of government—

TALK.START.PARA: —No.
—That is what you are saying.
—Owned by the Australian people; two-thirds owned even under your plan.

—Let us not pretend that it is owned by the Australian people. That is a complete myth, as we well know. When Mr Keating wanted to appropriate $400 million or $600 million to plug his budget deficit, he did not ask the Australian people about it. He simply got the chief executive in and said, `This is what I want you to do. Sell off Yellow Pages and give me a billion dollars or so, otherwise I'm going to impose special dividends on it.'

—That is conceding my point but then arguing that somehow we ought to disgorge your ill‐gotten gains; thank you for making the point. But the fact is that it is utterly irrelevant to suggest that somehow the best interests of Australian shareholders, or the Australian public themselves as shareholders, are being protected. They are not. This is treating the company at the whim of government, leaving the company open to all sorts of very undesirable political interferences.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said to you, the last thing that democracy and the people at large should want to see is a government having the ability to say, `We've got a couple of marginal seats. We want you to roll out services in those areas.' You dress that up and call it the national interest. The national interest is as long and as broad as you want it to be. No-one has ever attempted to define the national interest in any specific way, because it simply is the ultimate judgment that a government makes about what it ought to do and to what extent it ought to be accountable to the jury of public opinion.

But that is not the way to run a company. If members of the public bought some of the one-third shares that are on sale, do you really think they would be happy with the ability of a government to step in and tell the board that it ought to act non-commercially, that it ought to somehow take your view of what the national interest is, that somehow it ought to regard itself as being a social entity? It is not, and it has not been since 1991; the world changed then.

Until that time it was simply a government department, effectively, and you could do what you liked with it. But the whole concept of corporatisation was to require government business enterprises to act commercially. That is why the power contained in section 9 has never been used. BREAK.PARA: If you have an overriding power where a government can say, `Sorry, I want you to give me another $400 million to $600 million,' you can fundamentally jeopardise that company's business plan. If you tell it to go out and do things that it would not otherwise do because you think those things are in the national interest, you are requiring that company to act in a very uncommercial fashion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which is exactly what you are planning to do with the appropriations. That is exactly what you are planning to do. They don't have to do it.

—You could give them money or offer them money, but you cannot require them to take directions if you have given up that ability.

—That is precisely the point. The company is not there to act as though it is somehow an extension of what you define to be in the national interest or some sort of vehicle for social reform. What we want it to do is deliver those services wherever it can, as cheaply as possible, to the highest level of quality possible, and it does all those things.

BREAK.PARA: To the extent it falls short of doing those things, there is the capacity of government to do something. TALK.START.PARA: —And do what with them?

—You can do all sorts of things that you might regard as being socially desirable or in the national interest. But, if you do it in the context of telling a company which ought to be acting commercially that you will require it to somehow not act commercially because you want it to act in some other way, you are defeating the whole concept of a government business enterprise. It is no longer that. It is simply a government entity or department that does whatever the government of the day wants it to do.

BREAK.PARA: I did not think we had ever taken that view of Telstra. The view we have taken since 1991 is that we want it to compete effectively and deliver the best quality services at the lowest possible prices, and, to the extent there are any shortfalls in that, we impose certain requirements. If we say it would not otherwise have provided untimed local calls, we legislate for them. If we say it would not otherwise have provided services in rural and remote areas and we want it to do that, we impose a universal service obligation to ensure that it happens and we recoup the funds quite transparently from other carriers—and on it goes.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you have always had this power.

I am saying to you the reason it has not been exercised is that there has been a recognition that it conflicts with the commercial operations of the company. If you then have a company that is susceptible to a government giving it directions on the basis of what the government of the day regards as being in the national interest, there is absolutely no guar antee that that company will not find itself saddled with quite extraordinary burdens that might be quite uneconomic, which might make it quite unprofitable and therefore significantly reduce its capacity to compete and to deliver better quality services and lower prices to consumers.
