TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with great pleasure that I present to the Senate tonight a progress report on the implementation of the policies in the coalition's special Tasmania package, which formed a key part of election commitments to Tasmania. The Tasmania package was unveiled by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) in Hobart in February. Barely nine months have passed and already Tasmanians are reaping the very real benefits from policies contained in the Tasmania package.

SPEECH.PARA: Tasmania, due to its physical isolation and smaller population, has borne the brunt of Labor's 13 years of mismanagement. It was not just Labor's reckless handling of the economy which hurt Tasmanians but an attitude under Labor that the needs of a small state like Tasmania counted for little. We saw that attitude again the other day from Senator Kernot over the Telstra (Dilution of Public Ownership) Bill. Tasmania's best interests were too often sacrificed on Labor's altar of political convenience. Decisions were taken in Canberra to win the votes of people in Melbourne and Sydney at the expense of Tasmanians.

I want to speak tonight especially about the Bass Strait passenger vehicle equalisation scheme, because it represents a new era of opportunity for Tasmanians. One of the most exciting components of the package is the passenger vehicle equalisation scheme. It is already providing a very welcome injection of confidence and growth for Tasmania's important tourism industry.

The scheme is modelled on the freight equalisation scheme, which was introduced in the 1970s by the Fraser government. It operates on the very fair and straightforward principle which seeks to equalise the cost of travelling Bass Strait with a car with what other Australians pay when travelling interstate on federally funded national highways.

Since the introduction of the scheme on 1 September, just under six months since the coalition took office, the results have been quite simply spectacular. In the eight-week period to the end of October, there had been a 49 per cent increase in passenger bookings on the Spirit of Tasmania. For the current financial year, passenger bookings on the Spirit of Tasmania are up by more than 30 per cent, to 166,563 passengers.

The increase in passenger vehicle bookings has been a massive 93 per cent. Importantly, 70 per cent of the new bookings were for travel south from Melbourne to Devonport. The unprecedented surge in calls to the TT Line reservations centre has led to the employment of eight extra people to cope with the demand. These are the very real, positive and immediate results of just one component of the Tasmania package. We are looking forward to a continuing growth in the number of people crossing Bass Strait with their cars and entrenching the concept of a national highway link between the mainland and Tasmania.
The success of the scheme also puts to rest the harping of the Labor Party—

TALK.START.PARA: —Passenger numbers have actually gone down.

—And we are hearing that harping again right now from Senator Murphy—and demonstrates just how out of touch they were. Labor had no credibility on the Bass Strait transport issues in any case. Last year, despite growing enthusiasm for the rebate principle, Mr Keating came to Tasmania and told people who wanted to get to the mainland that they could fly across Bass Strait, and there was no need for a passenger vehicle rebate scheme. Tens of thousands of people, travelling with their cars, have since proven him wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: Faced with the prospect of defeat in Bass at the March election, Labor produced, in Mr Keating's words, `a great big lump of money' to buy a new fast ferry. Such was Labor's commitment to the issue—a minute‐to‐midnight decision to throw a lump of money at Bass Strait instead of a considered and long‐term solution. However, Labor missed the boat and the coalition rebate scheme has proven itself a vastly superior option which has been well received by Tasmanians and people travelling to Tasmania from interstate.

It is also worth remembering that the Labor Party in Tasmania had a carping approach to the scheme, none more so than Senator Shayne Murphy just prior to the introduction of the rebate scheme. Special segments of the visitor market are already finding the new scheme beneficial. For example, the Examiner of 11 November reported:
Record numbers of Victorian anglers have been enticed to Tasmanian lakes over the past week by the Bass Strait fare subsidy, the Freshwater Anglers Council of Tasmania said.
Executive officer Harvey Taylor said that record numbers of Victorians had visited Arthurs Lake and Lake Burbury in their own cars and boats last weekend and during the week.
Mr Taylor added that, thanks to the rebate, it was now very economical for interstate anglers to visit Tasmania's renowned lakes, and he expected the numbers to keep rising.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's true.

—Perhaps Senator Murphy does not like the competition at the lake. George Mure of Mures Restaurant in Hobart said only on Sunday that his business had increased by at least 15 per cent since the passenger equalisation scheme. On my recent visit to the Tasmanian tourist bureau in Melbourne, they said that they had not seen bookings like it since about 1992.

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition has also reaffirmed its longstanding commitment to freight equalisation. The coalition will put the scheme on a rolling five‐year basis, assuring Tasmanian business and industry of much greater certainty than ever before. Until now, the freight equalisation scheme has been little more than a year to year proposition. A review of rates of assistance for freight equalisation has been under way. There has been concern in some quarters that the federal government is cutting support for freight equalisation. It is not. By putting the freight equalisation scheme on a five‐year basis, we are shoring up the scheme, and putting it on a much more certain footing for the future.

In the Tasmania package, the coalition has fairly and squarely tackled the transport disadvantage caused by Bass Strait. We now have both passenger vehicles and freight covered by equalisation schemes which are delivering substantial and long‐term benefits to Tasmania, and it is no thanks to a Labor government that either of those measures were put in place.

Turning now to the Nixon inquiry, the Tasmania package also contains several other significant initiatives which should be mentioned. One of them was a review of Tasmania's employment and industry to update the Callaghan report of 1976. The inquiry will be chaired by Mr Peter Nixon, who is extremely well qualified for the task. In the Mercury at the weekend, there was a very interesting article by Michael Lester on an interview with Mr Nixon, and a description of how well qualified he is for the job. As a former senior federal minister, he has extensive experience in government and industry. His inquiry has wide ranging terms of reference, which basically seek to identify opportunities for Tasmania to develop its economy, the issues which need to be addressed to make that happen and the strategies which should be put in place. It will be an important report which will help chart the future for Tasmania and focus attention on opportunities for our state.

The federal government has also committed funding for the cleaning up of Tasmania's waterways. Eight million dollars will be spent over three years to improve water quality and social amenity in the Derwent, Tamar and Huon rivers. Funding has also been provided for further work to improve the water quality of the King River and Macquarie Harbour on the west coast, both of which have been degraded by mining operations over the past century.

Given the very special role played by Tasmania's rivers and waterways in our fishing and tourism industries, and various recreational pursuits, this initiative will be of enduring benefit to all Tasmanians. It also underlines the importance this government places on the environment.

We are also supporting significant projects in our cities and towns which reflect the diversity of the Tasmanian experience. In Launceston, the federal government is providing $7 million over three years to continue the Inveresk rail yards project started by the previous government. That will have immense social and cultural benefits for the city and northern Tasmania.

The project has already taken shape under funding provided, as I said, by the previous government. The funding to be provided by this government will ensure that the project realises its full potential. It is a visionary project which has generated great excitement, and full marks go to all those who have seen its future potential. An open day is to be held at the Inveresk site this Saturday, and I would encourage as many people as possible to visit and see how the revitalisation of Inveresk is taking place.

The Tasmania package also included a promise of funding of $2.5 million over three years for the International Antarctic Centre which is being created at Salamanca Place in Hobart. As you know, Hobart has an historic and continuing connection with Antarctica.

Another project that reflects some of the Tasmanian heritage is the axemen's hall of fame project at Latrobe in the state's north-west. The sport of woodchopping may not get the media attention or following of some of the better established sports, but it has had a long and colourful history and has widespread popular appeal. The government will be providing $150,000 over three years towards the establishment of a hall of fame to help preserve and promote this intrinsic part of our heritage.

The Tasmania package is a visionary and comprehensive collection of initiatives specially tailored to the unique needs of Tasmania as an island state. The measures announced in the package and now being put into place will be of lasting benefit to Tasmania. They are a real recognition of the concern which this government has for Tasmania and the emphasis it gives to helping Tasmanians develop special opportunities for their state. It gives me great and deep satisfaction that the new coalition government has already taken strong action to honour its election commitments to the people of Tasmania and to give them hope for the future.

But it was Mr Grahame Morris that suggested—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the role, function and purpose of parliamentary privilege in the Western Australian parliament in light of the Commission on Government recommendations. The term `parliamentary privilege' refers to the powers, rights and immunities held by parliament, members of parliament and parliamentary committees. It enables parliamentarians to be able to do their job without fear or interference. Parliamentary privilege prohibits anything said or done by members in the course of parliamentary proceedings from being questioned or impeached in any court or tribunal.

SPEECH.PARA: Parliamentary privilege is one of the fundamental principles which maintains the separation of powers in our system of government. On rare but significant occasions, parliamentary privilege has led to conflict between the courts and parliaments. One of the most significant was the clash between the Senate and the Supreme Court of New South Wales during the trials of High Court judge Lionel Murphy.

Parliamentarians have to be able to expose corruption and misgovernment, must be able to fully and fearlessly scrutinise the actions of government, the public service and the judiciary, and to inquire into matters of public concern. For these reasons it is necessary that the rights of citizens or the state to take legal action against parliamentarians be circumscribed by parliamentary privilege in order that the essential and larger freedoms of a democratic society are preserved.

Parliamentary privilege had its origins in the English parliamentarians' battle against the power of the English monarchy in the 17th century. The result was article 9 of the Bill of Rights of 1689 which stated that:
Freedom of speech and debates or proceedings in parliament ought not to be impeached or questioned in any court or place out of parliament.

As you would know, at that stage the executive was not part of parliament. Historically, the intention of parliamentary privilege was to protect parliamentarians from influence and threat by the executive, which was then the Crown. Now the executive is in the parliament and enjoys the protection of parliamentary privilege. What is more, the executive dominates parliament, particularly in this parliament in the lower house. The result has been that the executive can use parliamentary privilege to shield itself from full accountability.

The detrimental effects of the shielding of the executive from full accountability through the use of parliamentary privilege was highlighted during the work of the royal commission into WA Inc. in 1992. It is believed that parliamentary privilege for the executive acted to prevent the full exposure of corrupt, illegal and improper conduct by public officials and the executive as members of parliament. It is my belief that, if properly pursued, a lot more people would have felt the full weight of the law otherwise.

In the interests of preventing this from re‐occurring, the Commission on Government made a number of recommendations which addressed the concerns of the royal commission, members of parliament and the community. The principal recommendations include the clarification of the proceedings in parliament which are subject to parliamentary privilege, as in the Commonwealth legislation; the establishment of standing committees to make determinations on the breaches of privilege codes; and the provision of a right to reply where there are allegations of an abuse of parliamentary privilege.

BREAK.PARA: The Commission on Government made a number of recommendations with respect to the abuse of parliamentary privilege. Principally, a standing committee on privilege should be established in each house of parliament. The committee would be responsible for the creation of a code of conduct to serve as a guide for members in relation to possible breaches of parliamentary privilege. The standing committee, the Commission on Government recommended, should also be responsible for reviewing conduct alleged to be in breach of the code. The commission recommended that, in the event of a breach of the code of conduct being established, the standing committee should recommend an appropriate penalty to the house concerned. Depending upon the seriousness of the conduct, the commission recommended the penalty could be a retraction and/or apology, suspension from the House for a period up to 14 days, or forfeiture of the member's seat. Those are strong recommendations.

The Commission on Government was particularly concerned, in response to the extensive public hearings and complaints on parliamentary privilege, that the recommendations, once adopted, be reassessed after three years. The satisfaction of community concerns on this issue was of particular relevance to the commission's findings. I would remind this parliament that the recent occurrences in the New South Wales parliament indicate how current and how fierce are the passions about parliamentary privilege.

The reviews the Commission on Government recommended should include public hearings to afford members of the public the opportunity to express their views and to enable the standing committees to judge community sentiment. Finally, the Commission on Government recommended that, if the standing committees find that the incidences of abuse have not been reduced to the satisfaction of the community, then the parliament should appoint an independent commissioner responsible for investigating and overseeing the use of parliamentary privilege.

A crucial element to the Commission on Government's recommendations was the provision of a right of response by citizens and organisations to enable them to answer statements made under parliamentary privilege. This is a recommendation I advocate for all the parliaments of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon, Sen David

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to speak on the annual report of ASIO, the debate of which was abandoned when government business was stood aside today. I would like to thank Senator Calvert for volunteering to Senator Campbell to stand aside on the adjourment tonight. This report that was before the Senate today is the annual report of ASIO, which deals with internal security. The purpose of ASIO is to protect our people and our property from those who would do us harm. Regrettably, the need for that is as great as it ever was.

SPEECH.PARA: ASIO, it is popularly thought, is mainly concerned with Soviet agents. But that is not true at present and it really never was true. It always has had a very wide area of interest. Some of the things it is principally concerned with are: politically motivated violence from minority groups and sections within the community, espionage, and the taking of intellectual property from Australian industry and from Australian institutions. It also has a very important role, as outlined in page 5 of the report, in relation to nuclear, chemical and biological weapons—weapons of mass destruction, their precursors and even the testing of them within Australia. It is not generally known how important that field is within ASIO.

The report that was presented to the parliament today is very much an abridged version—all the sensitive areas and all the areas that are interesting to read have been deleted. Nevertheless, it gives a fair oversight of the range of activities carried out by this authority.

One of my regrets on reading the report is that more mention was not made of the retiring Director-General, Mr David Sadleir, who retired last month as the Director-General of ASIO. David Sadleir is self-effacing, intelligent, shrewd and possesses a sound and mature judgment. He was one of the best director-generals ASIO has had. He came in as director-general at a time when the authority was particularly run down and in a lot of trouble. When he left only a month or so ago, he left the organisation in very good condition. I wish him well in his retirement. On behalf of the parliament and the public, I would like to thank him for what he did through those years with what is a very important institution within the Australian community. I welcome his successor, Mr Dennis Richardson, who brings a great deal of enthusiasm and dedication to the job. I know he will perform very well in that role.

The ending of the Cold War at the end of the 1980s has not eliminated in any way the need for the security and intelligence organisations that we have in this country. One of the great needs in those organisations is maintaining constant surveillance of their internal security, of their own personnel, and the handling of information. That is often not publicly recognised. But the penalties for not doing that are very high.

The Senate will remember three years ago when Aldrich James, a CIA agent, was exposed as having been working for the Russians. He had a 10-year period of betrayal before he was detected. The price of his betrayal was enormous and was a consequence of a failure of internal security within the CIA. For example, in his first year of operation, in 1985, he betrayed 13 American CIA agents—nine of whom were executed and three of whom ended in prison.

PARA.BREAK: In recent months, a similar case, also in the CIA, has been exposed—the Nicholson case. The interesting thing about the Nicholson case is that it was not an ideologically driven betrayal. It was not that Nicholson in any way at all was attracted to the Soviets. He was a person with an impeccable record in the armed services and special forces, very much an all American. But he got into a great deal of difficulty with an expensive divorce settlement. It illustrates one of the problems that we have at present. People who are in need of money—and large sums of money—in a hurry are as much a security risk, and probably more so in the present ideologically free envi ronment, than those who have a commitment to a particular set of ideals.

SPEECH.PARA: That leads me on to the matter of accountability and oversight of ASIO and the rest of the security organisations. Ideally, of course, the minister responsible for the security agency is accountable to the parliament. Unfortunately, as the last speaker was hinting, in his talk about parliamentary privilege, an executive government is not always able to be as accountable as it should be. The need for an alternative system or a supporting system in the form of committee oversight from the parliament itself is a crucial part of a modern democratic society.

ASIO operates within the law, within the statutory limits that are laid down under the act that set it up under the Labor government back in the late 1940s. So far as I know, it has never breached or exceeded those statutory limits. It is under the control of the Attorney-General and is answerable to him. The Attorney-General, though, is always one of the busiest ministers in any government. All other departments are constantly referring to the Attorney‐General a great deal of work for advice and legal opinions.

As in the case of ASIS, one of our other security agencies, answerable to the foreign minister, what happens is that the security agencies are answerable to ministers who are in cabinet, who are very busy and who simply cannot put the time into the oversight for which they have to accept responsibility.

ASIO is also under the umbrella of the Director-General of Security, who looks at its activities. This year's report defines the duties of the Inspector‐General as being to see that ASIO acts legally and with propriety, complies with ministerial guidelines and directives and has due regard to human rights and civil liberties. He may inquire into complaints against ASIO by the public, into matters referred to him by the Attorney‐General or into other matters at his own discretion. But, again, basically the Inspector‐General is there to see that ASIO does not do something that breaches the law.

Finally, we come to the parliamentary committee of which I am the chairman. It was a very bold move roughly 10 years ago when the Labor government that was then in power amended the ASIO Act, introduced section 5A and set up a parliamentary committee. That was a great advance forward at the time, but time moves on. There is a demonstrable need now, compared with other democratic societies, to increase that level of parliamentary oversight and accountability. It is not a matter of how that should be done, but when it should be done. My belief is that the time is now upon us when changes should be made to the ASIO Act, because section 5A is extraordinarily restrictive. The parliamentary committee which is charged with oversight of the organisation is denied any inquiry into any matters that ASIO has that derive from foreign intelligence, involve foreign nationals, involve any operational matters or involve complaints against the organisation. In fact, it can only deal with matters referred to it by the Attorney-General. That is a very great restriction on its operations. It cannot exercise the oversight that a democratic parliament demands.

What we need to do in this parliament is alter the act. We need to put all the intelligence agencies under the umbrella, the oversight, of a parliamentary committee. You will remember that, when Mr Justice Samuels inquired into ASIS, there was a proposal that a new committee be set up to oversee ASIS. I would be strongly opposed to that. I think that the parliament only needs one intelligence and security committee. It should look at all the agencies. The responsibilities of that committee should be defined in the terms of the British act which sets up their Intelligence and Security Committee—that is, that the parliamentary committee should examine the expenditure, administration and policies relating to operational matters while not involving itself in day-to-day activities. It keeps those secure, but allows the parliament to exercise effective oversight and be accountable to the public for the actions of those agencies.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Diesel Fuel Spill at Groote Eylandt

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Senator Lees

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 1 November 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the diesel fuel oil spill by Gemco at Groote Eylandt:
(1) How much diesel fuel oil was ordered by Gemco for use on Groote Eylandt for each of the past 5 years.
(2)(a) How much diesel fuel oil has been spilled; (b) how was this calculation made; and (c) where has the fuel been spilled.
(3) Can a map be provided of Groote Eylandt showing all Gemco facilities and areas of diesel fuel spilt.

(4)(a) Has any fuel been located in the marine environment; (b) have there been any tests on the marine environment to see if there has been any diesel oil entering; and (c) what tests have been conducted on the marine environment and what were the results of each of these tests.
(5)(a) Have there been any tests on marine life for diesel or any signs of contact with diesel; and (b) what tests have been conducted on marine life and what were the results of these tests.

(6)(a) Have there been any reports of diesel spills or has diesel been detected in the marine environment of the area; (b) what testing has the company done to pinpoint the exact location of all the diesel; and (c) what are the results of testing conducted by the company to pinpoint those locations.
(7)(a) When did the Government first request information from Gemco in relation to the diesel fuel spill; and (b) what information was requested by the Government.
(8) Could a copy be provided of all documents sent between the company and the Government about the diesel spill on Groote Eylandt.
(9) Is the company providing all information about the spill and all test results and data to the Federal Government.

(10) In a recent answer to a question without notice from Senator Lees, the Minister said that an extensive search of customs and company records would be needed to prove whether or not the diesel fuel rebate had been paid for oil spilt on Groote Eylandt: (a) will the Government undertake this search; and (b) will the company be asked to provide its records.
(11) How did the company assess how much diesel fuel rebate was claimable.
(12) Why is the administration of the scheme so complicated that something like this is hard to examine.

(13)(a) Has the Government considered appointing a special auditor to examine administration and potential rorting of the diesel fuel rebate scheme; and (b) is the appointment of a special auditor likely to happen.
(14) Does the Minister agree that taxpayer's money may be used to support claims under the diesel fuel rebate scheme which are not accurate to the intent of the rebate.
(15) Can a list of the amounts involved in all allegations of rorting under the scheme in the past 5 years be provided.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: — The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) GEMCO has publicly stated that they order and use approximately 25 million litres of diesel each year.

(2)(a) GEMCO has retained consultants who have estimated that the maximum volume of fuel in the ground is approximately 3 million litres. (b) This amount is calculated from information obtained as a result of an extensive drilling program that provides information on thickness of fuel in the ground, surface area of the plume and the porosity of the soil. (c) Fuel loss has occurred in the vicinity of GEMCO's fuel facilities at Milner Bay.

(3)-(6) I do not have such a map. Regulatory responsibility for this matter rests with the Northern Territory Government. I understand GEMCO has kept the Northern Territory Government fully informed and that the Northern Territory Government is satisfied that GEMCO is taking appropriate remedial action.

(7)(a) The Australian Customs Service (ACS) requested information in a letter dated 1 February 1996. (b) The information requested was whether rebate had been claimed for any of the leaked fuel and the request was made in the context of a routine enquiry for information on a number of matters required to consider the company's rebate claim.
(8) No. These documents contain commercial information and were provided to the Government in confidence.
(9) No. I have asked GEMCO to keep me informed on the environmental management of the leakage but this will not entail duplication of the Northern Territory Government's regulatory role.
(10) The ACS is to conduct a full audit of the company's diesel fuel rebate claims and payments. The company has indicated it will co-operate fully with the audit.

(11) The audit referred to in 10 above will determine the basis for assessment of rebate claimable. It is my understanding that the company has claimed rebate for leaked fuel and the extent to which this has occurred will be examined in the audit. As I stated on 17 October, the company has advised me that the leaked fuel is being recovered, cleaned, and re-used for activities which would be eligible for diesel fuel rebate. BHP acknowledges that when clean up operations are complete, there will be some fuel left in the ground that will not be recovered. BHP has indicated that it is willing to negotiate a realistic adjustment to rebate payments based on an agreed and, if necessary, independent estimate of the lost fuel on which rebate has been claimed, and that will be a matter for decision by the Minister and Customs in due course.
(12) Diesel fuel rebate is payable on purchases of fuel for use in eligible activities as defined under legislation. Payment of rebate is based on prospective use for eligible activities.
In the very unusual circumstances which exist in this case, it is necessary to determine the basis on which rebate was claimed and whether the claim meets the requirements of the legislation.
This will be done in the audit.
The Government has announced that legislation to be introduced shortly will specifically cover circumstances such as occurred in this case.

(14) The Government announced in the Budget that measures would be put in place to clamp down on misuse of the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme. Legislation to give effect to these measures is expected to be introduced shortly.

(15) It is not possible to provide this material. Allegations of fraud are investigated and, as recently indicated by the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs, who is responsible for the administration of the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme, diesel fuel claimants who attempt to defraud the Commonwealth will be prosecuted. In two recent cases, prosecution resulted in claimants receiving prison sentences.
